Ty22tTUFmoWZoIwXY8HfRw.text: Another awesome stop on my first visit to Pittsburgh.  Penn Brewery is such a nice brewery to check out if you are in the area.  Pitt has a lot of small breweries around town and it might be hard to pick one but Penn Brewery is a must stop in my opinion.  Coming from Florida we have some amazing local brewers to choose from (Funky Buddha, Due South, etc) so I was excited to see what Pitt had to offer.  The building itself is very beautiful, all brick and very open in the front they even have outdoor seating when the weather is warm.  When you walk in all you can see is a big open and beautiful dining area, a huge bar and the brewery itself you can see through the glass.  There is also a downstairs area but we didn't go down there we stayed at the top to eat and drink.  When we sat down we got the bad news that they were out of the Pumpkin beer (it was October so they said they go through it fast).  So we decided to try the 10 glass sample of beer instead and it was perfect for the 3 of us.  We really loved the beer even the IPA they had was really interesting.  My favorite was the Penn Dark and my niece really like the Penn Gold.  The food....  We came in for lunch after working up a pretty good appetite walking around town.  There is a big polish influence in Pitt so there are lots of things on the menu that show that influence (think pirogues, and schnitzels).  I ordered the Schnitzel Sandwich (breaded pork cutlet sauteed and topped with grilled peppers, onions, mushrooms, vinegar slaw, Swiss cheese and Dijon mustard).  O M G!  This was delicious!!  I ate all of this sandwich I could not put it down.  It came with German potato salad, which apparently has vinegar in it and I wasn't a fan of that flavor combo.  It wasn't bad just not my thing.  I only ordered it at the suggestion of the server but I think it was more of a personal taste type thing.  My friend got the mac and cheese and it was good she ate it all.  The only thing I would say is she thought it was a bit greasy as it came with a lot of oil covering the top from the cheese.  My niece ordered the Kielbasa Reuben Sandwich, Pitts twist on a classic (thin sliced kielbasa, sauerkraut, thousand island dressing, Swiss cheese, and a potato pancake on grilled pumpernickel bread).  She loved it and there was nothing left of the sandwich she killed it. Definitely check out Penn Brewery if you can and get the Schnitzel Sandwich!!

rS1K8riiptPKz__OPZWbSQ.text: Delicious food and super engaging staff. Tried the five beer flight and split a chocolate meltdown. Had the Wurst Baguette and the kielbasa had a phenomenal snap. Add some mustard and sauerkraut to the toasted pretzel roll and it was unbeatable. Got the cheese curds for an appetizer and the crunchy breading with mustard was delicious too. I'd come back any time.

TdcmHleEu3rclzbasAcy_Q.text: Last weekend our travels took us to the West side of PA, a little known town by the name of Pittsburgh.  While visiting friends and family, the minute we walked into the door before our bags even hit the floor, our hosts said 5 words.  "Let's go to a brewery."  The dude abides.  So despite just getting out of a car we were in for 7+ hours, it was right back into one, as we headed to Penn Brewery.  On the north side of town, Penn Brewery is the Burgh's oldest and largest brew house, and we were   happy to pay a visit.  As you see from our photos, its attempts to model itself after European Beer gardens is a welcome sight.  Apparently this part of town was heavy on the German settlers, so they had their influences correct.  But how was the beer?  Here are a few we sampled with some notes.  1.  Penn Pilsner - this is their flagship.  They pride themselves on it.  A German style brewery prides itself on a Bohemian style beer.  Interesting.  They claim it's smooth & mellow.  I was not alone at our table when I say it was neither.  It was bitter, it was in your face hops, it was heavy.  Light to the eyes, heavy to the gut.  Not a fan.  This was a NO.    2.  Penn Dark - This one would be more my style.  Dark, heavy, Munich style Dunkel.  It had what a dark should have.  Roasty malt scents and flavors, a bit of bitter countered with a bit of sweet, still a little heavy on the hops, but a big improvement over the Pilsner.  This was a YES.    3. Penn Weizen - We are all familiar with this style, the nice Bavarian wheat.  Several award winner according to them, including a Men's Journal top 25 beers in America.  Bold statement.  But it stood up to the test.  This is one of my favorite styles, I could tell easily if you screwed it up.  Penn gets a YESon this one.     4. St. Nikolaus Bock - Very malty, extremely dark and heavy, warming gut, sweetness to the taste and the nose, this was the one.  If we had had this one around Christmas time it may have been a winner.  Or very close 2nd.  This was a good one, my fave of the day, and would definitely get again.  YES.  Unfortunately the road weariness played a huge part in how few beers we sampled this night.  But what started out negatively with the Pilsner, ended very strong with the Nikolaus.  Penn Brewery is more than OK in our books.  Wrap Up;  Had some TVs ready to watch the Pens game, decent different beers, and nice menu of apps.  Good alternative to a sports bar for sure.

5ZcHadWDZNPgp3RL4EuYPw.text: Lederhosen Optional!  My first visit was Oktoberfest.  Oktoberfest was a blast!   Great people, good beer, and tons of character / atmopshere for the event.   Penn Brewery throws a great party.   I have been to some pretty large Oktoberfest (Cincinnati) where all of downtown is closed.    This place had all the character and fun as the larger festivals.  The place was packed - always a good sign.   The beer was awesome.   I did not try the food - but it looked good as well.  Beer - Great Variety, Good Value, and Great Service (Served by the brewmasters themself) Price - Pretty good but will wait until "post Oktoberfest) Atmosphere - Very neat.   a little courtyard, inside was nice / very German feel  Overall - a great place to check out.   I will be back.

IVjuU4AfddcsYc5Gzayimw.text: I really enjoyed stopping by Penn Brewery for beers last Friday afternoon before heading to the Wigle Whiskey Garden and Barrelhouse. I appreciated the small parking lot adjacent to the brewery that made finding a spot much easier than trolling the narrow north side streets. I ordered a Ginger Beer and a few pierogies, which were both very tasty. Though the interior of Penn Brewery was nice, I really enjoyed sitting outside. Even though it was pretty warm in the sun, it was the perfect temperature in their shaded courtyard. I could have relaxed here for hours. I would definitely like to come back sometime soon!

50dBLIRTkr-0O5CTH2EaeA.text: Went here as a group of 6 people, all with diff dietary restrictions, and all walked out of that place, satisfied, satiated, and happy.  Food was beyond delicious and reasonably priced. We even walked away with 5 growlers of beer!   My only quips are a. My bf ordered a well done burger, and it was given to him medium, at best b. All the food is well priced, except for mine. I ordered a pirogi dish, and was given 3 pieces, I know it's an app, but for 7.00 I expected more.  Other than that, thank you for a delicious meal.

XbVFZARzM2sv43U9SamIpA.text: We hadnt been here in years. Unfortunately the quality of the food has seriously declined. The buffalo cauliflower was undercooked florets coated in red hot and Kraft blue cheese dressing. My flat bread was soggy.  My husband's German Reuben wasnt good either. The beer was ok. The service was very good but we left feeling pretty disappointed.

GeZsbSoqbCP0K_oU3MOBSA.text: If you're in the mood for a German bierhalle with good beer & solid food, this is your spot. Large tables with big wooden benches & equally big servings of food & beer. I grew up in Germany, & the food was definitely True to style. Not necessarily the best German food I've had in the States, but still very good--& reasonably priced.  All of the brews were good, but the dark, malty doppelbock--St Nik, I think--was delicious. The beer bumped it up to 4 stars.

ciDQSA-VHoxB1pAvvhXmVQ.text: Penn Brewery has a great atmosphere and reminds me of a more "local" version of the big chain German beer restaurant you can find in South Side works. Their draft list has a selection of favorites and some seasonal choices, all brewed in house. My husband and I elected to share some apps, the German potato salad, Pierogies, and potato pancakes. The pancakes were dynamite! The menu looks promising and the inviting atmosphere makes me want to come back sometime in the spring or summer, especially since I noticed that the bike trail goes directly to their little private parking lot. Looking forward to a return visit!

D0C_w1SoGbNFBlsfQU30UQ.text: We were very excited for our first trip to Penn Brewery! Our server was helpful, informative, and attentive! The beers were great and the food was amazing! The atmosphere was up beat and we even had football to watch! I will be back when I'm in Pittsburgh!

ilhAS9PHKl82giamE4C_AQ.text: Being a beer lover, I had to try this place on a recent visit to Pittsburgh.  The restaurant is German themed, with a large beer garden where you eat at communal picnic tables. There is also an indoor area that is much less charming.  If you are reserving a table, be sure to specify if you want the beer garden.  On the night of our visit there was a German accordion band playing, which provided a lot of (kind of corny) entertainment though it was a bit loud. The band obviously has a few fans who come regularly wearing their t shirts and at times get up to dance to the music.  The beer was good, I especially liked the Penn Weizen.  We tried a few others that were ok but not memorable.  As to the food, the fresh pretzel with beer cheese was a good starter. For the entrees I would recommend the Polish Hill Plate, which came with kielbasa, perogies and sauerkraut. This item was  far better than the breaded pork schnitzel which I found to be greasy and too large a portion of meat. The sides of applesauce and red cabbage were only so so.  Overall, a fun evening, I think that one visit will be enough, but we enjoyed it for what it was.

oHzpyUj0_kQ6U-uqwKe0kw.text: As a tourist I would say this is a must see if you like drinking in old cool buildings. Go at night, go outside and take a pic by the Heinz factory then eat some food and go home.

Njh6LQxWRLBK20CfRWnr3Q.text: Cool old building nice interior great staff.  Cool looking at brew stations behind large glass. .German beers are prominent though they offer pale ale & IPA each of these have a German flare.  Not saying that's bad just don't expect typical American beer styles.  Burger  & fries were good.

3EkJbq4KjQmaL7oMixyh8g.text: Went in with the bf for drinks and food. Beer was decent and the food tasted very bland. Shocked because we heard so many great things!

4MIsXpRH42G_sXHbrM30Gg.text: I ate here for dinner this past Thursday night with a dining companion.  The decor of the restaurant makes it look like a beer hall from Germany with long benches and tables.  You are also able to see a fermentation tank which is nice since you are at a brewery.  For dinner my dining companion and I started off by sharing the Buffalo Chicken Pierogi appetizer.  I was excited about them and they did not disappoint with every part being very good, especially the chicken filling.  For my entree I ordered a beef roll that came with braised red cabbage and German potato salad.  The potato salad ended up being the best part of the meal for me with the beef roll being average and the red cabbage disappointing.  The reason for this being that it had a very strong tasting spice that I could not completely identify (caraway maybe?) which I have never had in red cabbage before.  So in the end the pierogi appetizer stole the show for myself.  The bottom line for me is that I would probably head back here again.  There were plenty of items on the menu that I would like to try and the appetizer was good enough that they still intrigue me.

lRtEqnRV35zcnFphx07j2g.text: This place is awesome.  The beer is excellent and the food is great.  It's a little loud- I was there on a Saturday night- but the vibe is casual and comfy.  Get something with the bier cheese.  Yum!

zaraC34XYS1lQSAZLWr6ng.text: I love beer and I really love the selection of beer at Penn Brewery. I've sampled the food from here and as a vegetarian, I give it a thumbs up. Not too many places care to have more than one vegetarian option but PB does. As for the beer, each selection is flavorful and unique. Any time my parents throw a party (in Philly) we take a few cases of Penn Brewery beer and it is always a hit.  The place itself is really really big and not only is it a fun drinking spot for a group of friends but families are also comfortable and welcome.

aLzw9cvG1BdFTOOgjHzjxQ.text: They were out of all the good beer each time I went. Then the last time I saw a mouse run across the floor while eating and was told that's normal... Haven't been back!

jghcXZFOCUbNtP7Q1CUQXQ.text: Some really good meals and some were average. Things to Get:  Potato Pancakes (excellent flavor), German Rueben (nice size portion), and Jaegerschnitzel (excellent entree) Things to avoid:  Buffalo Chicken Dip (Bland), Bier Cheese and Macaroni (no flavor), and Schweinebraten.  Also - Finish your beer before you ask for another.  When I asked for a beer, it was immediately poured from a pitcher into my current beer that was not even finished with yet.

bULFadZawYXDKfL4FiO-UA.text: We were there this past weekend WoW they cannot keep up with a crowd they totally screwed up our entire order there were eight of us could not get our orders straight some food came at the same time others did not Really we where ordering major drinks and food and still total disregard for the money that was being spent you need to train your staff on customer service try taking lessons from restaurants like Meditrano on Babcock Boulevard Nicki's Ty North Side Customer Service they will make or break you Group On don't fall for the discount not worth it Don't waste your money

58PN9XtWkm2JHF4XCU3MsQ.text: I had high expectations after looking them up online, seeing their friendly staff, tasty food, and great atmosphere. Unfortunately, the atmosphere and service was very disappointing. The food took a long time and the beers were tapped very messy. ALSO, you had to walk all the way around the building, then walk upstairs just to go back downstairs to find the restrooms. It was unacceptable considering they would not open a door that would have made the bathroom a lot closer. Overall disappointed.

DTtMykr9HoF_iUkHIqXyUQ.text: This is probably my favorite brewery in town based off the quality alone. They had like two fruity beers and one wheat with banana undertones which makes me want to do some day drinking on a regular basis! As for the other beers, even if it's not my typical choice they are still solid tasty beers. I heard from a local that this place has been around forever, but is starting to lose some business because of other establishments cooler appearance, outside games, dog friendly, etc. I can see the appeal in all the additions I just listed, but if you are in the mood for just good quality beer without all the other frills, this is the place to go! Oh and to top of the delicious beer, the food is really good here too!

fiwiH_PJ0ROh02T9oUXdDA.text: Visiting from out today of town. After imbibing at Southern Tier the night before, this was a huge step down. Beer was watery, bland and flavorless and lacked carbonation. The bartenders demeanor was colder than the beer. We left after half our flight and went to Allegheny Brewery instead.

m-OdtuX7y1JXwY83_Mnuqg.text: If you go get the cheese curds.  Best I've ever had!   Service was fast and friendly and beer delicious, 15 or more on tap.  Turn the lights up a bit though, could hardly see what I was eating or anything in the bar area.

m-hyeRNSbXOArJmKHrrAmg.text: The ambiance was great, the food was exceptional, and the beer was exactly what you would want from your local brewery.   I enjoyed a Reuben and a New Moon double dunkel.   My server was polite and kind of crass - which I very much enjoyed and only added to the euro-American atmosphere. It did take a few minutes for a host to seat us, so if you're in a hurry this might not be ideal, but if you're looking to take get your time and enjoy the company - this is the place.

171-nCQ-_ufC5sR_CFMvnA.text: What a nice night at the brewery! We sat outside and drank classic German beers and had a great dinner.  The last time we were there, we weren't as impressed with the food, so we've stayed away for a while. Maybe it was a different cook, but last night the food was fantastic.  I'm a huge fan of jaegerschnitzel and spaetzle, and it was cooked very well here.  We will be back!

zbzN_qcvguriPwKY9Hno9g.text: TLDR - Ok food/beer, God awful service.   We went to Penn Brewery after a hike on a nice warm day. We reached there at around 2:45 PM. It wasn't overly busy. Nobody received us, nobody seated us, the wait staff looked visibly annoyed but finally after 10-15 mins or roaming around aimlessly they got us seats. We were a group of 12 or so. I would think any restaurant would be happy to have our patronage at a time when the wait and kitchen staff had some slack.   Anyway, it took them over 30 mins to serve us water and even collect our orders. They were atleast 3 parties that came in after us and were served way before our orders came out. These people were done eating and were paying their bills before our food even came out! Our food came out 50 mins after we placed the order! Our food came out at 4:25PM when we walked in the door just around 2:45 on a lazy Sunday afternoon!! Our waitress gave us all kinds of attitude and wasn't apologetic in the least! The food was served at room temperature and was mediocre at best. Nothing anyone couldn't whip up on a George Foreman grill with some store bought sausages.   This was unequivocally the single worst restaurant experience I have had in Pittsburgh. The worst!  Give your business to people who appreciate it and take pride in putting out good quality product/service. Penn Brewery clearly doesn't.

u2cIQKBmIwbxCa49LVYfjw.text: Beer only!  Hubby says buy the beer and bring it home more enjoyable and affordable.   The food is nothing to rave about.  The service was off. The atmosphere was underwhelming.  The building exterior was very interesting.  It was a fun little maze from the parking garage to the front door.

l4ZBTYMHY_SYXDG0BSetNw.text: I had one of the most authentic German Hefeweizens that I have found in the US, and I lived in Bavaria for 2 years.  It didn't have the head like the German brews do, but was still plenty fizzy.  It is also the first place in the US I have seen a Doner Kebob on the menu.  This is a common fast-food sandwich in Germany, the Turkish version of the Greek Gyro.  The lamb meat on mine was finely shredded, but the overall sandwich was good.  The vinegary, warm German potato salad was tasty also.  I also sampled the fries, which were somewhat overdone, and the Buffalo cauliflower appetizer, which was good.  The atmosphere was fine.  The water refills were a bit tardy.

ZfUG-iCNONNXjE2Z7rGdCQ.text: I love the food and the beer. If they made it more warm as far as atmosphere this place would be crowned every night. That said we had the Jaugersnitzel and it is amazing.  As for the beer we get flights then you don't have to decide.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

wY5eXT36OSrx9GxM9LotiQ.text: Beer, Beer, and yes more Beer!! So me and my boyfriend were heading out to a local place for wings but we ended up getting side tracked to this little Brewery! I've heard on Penn Brewery but never had the chance to get there until now. I absolutely feel I love with the decor and the quaint brick building. The out door area with the brick road was super cute and gave it an European feel. It was obviously to cold to sit outside but would love to check it out when it's in full glory mode.  After we got inside and seated I checked out the beer menu. I loved how they had their own selection of beers. I was a bit disappointed That the beer I was told to try was out of stock so I ended up going with the Penn Dark which was so delicious I ended up drinking two of them  As for food I ordered the wild mushroom flat bread and the butcher plate for 2-3 people. Now don't get me wrong the mushroom flat bread was good but I was disappointed there were so few actual mushrooms on it. The butcher plate was excellent I lived all the different meats but you only got 2 kinds of cheese which I wish I had at least one more to try.  My boyfriend got the beef and lamb Doner Kebab that I didn't try but he raved that the lamb was especially tasty.  As for our server she was nice but when she reviewed our beer menu she went over which ones they had on tap and which ones were not which was great. Then I forgot which ones she didn't have an asked about a certain one that was not on tap and she got a bit annoyed and snippy with me. I was taken a bit back from but other then that our service was good.

jZF1lCeHWRBBkMoL0h9oDA.text: SO unbelievably loud, even without the indoor bands (is this place a restaurant or a venue for bad amateur bands?) Avoid if you'd like to have a conversation with the people you came with. Food not special enough to make up for migraine or hearing loss.

HHranm7x5963O5WWmF6hXA.text: I've been a few times- biggest down side for those who are gluten free; no beer options. I didn't see a wine list while I was there either. Another down side is the lack of gluten free dishes --going to Penn Brewery as a gluten free person is a typical "I guess I'm getting a salad" experience. However, I really enjoyed their grilled chicken salad- the chicken was cooked perfectly. It was a very nice portion size as well. I've also gotten the steak cob salad --pretty good too. Nothing out of this world, but I know my non-gluten free friends love the food and beer options.  They have a patio out back that looks like a fun time in warm weather to go with friends- I would go back just for the atmosphere.

0J2mTsF_p6MbTZfvPu4qYg.text: Fantastic home made style German food . Their poutine is amazing.  Friendly staff an well made brews. Definitely going back

dwT-YemI8JwEqIQhRHeRJA.text: Food was sub-par, service below average...not our best experience here. It seems to have gone downhill, what a shame. We used to love this place...will not return.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

-1ANaljn6dytZvS7XX1cNA.text: Full disclosure, German beer and food is a personal passion.  That said, Penn Brewery stands out among the really excellent similar establishments I've visited across the country.  My wife and I visited Pittsburgh recently (I love the town BTW), and we made a point of having brews and dinner there; we were not disappointed.    Food was very good; we had pork loin and the sausage platter as well as potato pancakes (delicious!).  We sampled their different brews, but the dark lager was clearly the favorite and it compared quite favorably to the best German brews that I have tasted over the years.  Our server was very attentive and we never had to wonder where he was.  The food was presented promptly as was the beer.  I'm looking forward to our next visit to this outstanding establishment.

qP6Mf7Ox8K-3ridEFiBWaA.text: The food was amazing.  We got the burger. It was one of the best burgers we've ever had.  It's great German American food all around.  The beer was really good. Our favorites we're the hefewizen, the nut roll, and the hot ginger beer.  All were great, uniquely delicious beers.

v2-aM3QhhYxZuBjTOp8vXw.text: I had someone take this place up big time. I thought it was a cute little spot but I wouldn't make a special trip for it. Now granted I didn't try their food so I may be delicious for all I know. The scenery is cool because you can see them brewing the beers behind a huge glass wall. It's a cozy place and if I'm in the area I would go here again but make it a point to try the food. They do have a full bar if you aren't in the mood for beer. The beer is refreshing and I also tried a margarita which was very good. Oh and btw you can park out front despite what the sign says.

xMt5pa3LlkVIhoRzJYvnIg.text: I am a huge fan of the Penn Brewery and if you don't know me I am a bit of a booze hound. I love beer! All types, all colors, all ABV's. So I ran in here today for lunch but I  am not allowed to imbibe during work hours. Woe is me....the world is not fair! My point is if you enjoy a beer, just about any type...this is the place to start. I have been here 10+ times and this was my only non-drinking visit.   I enjoyed the Braumeister Steak Sandwich with fries. The food, service and atmosphere were great. Try to find the time to visit this place. Well worth the stop.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Braumeister Steak sandwich

9wMz-K4aTPi31LoK_I_QFg.text: This place serves good beer and good brew pub food. I had the sausage platter. Loved to kielbasa and the Penn Pilsner bratwurst. Thought the chicken sausage was bland. The German hot potato salad tasted sweat. I thought it would almost be a dessert. My daughter had the chili. Good flavor not spicy. Son had the pirogis. I tried one of his, there was nothing special about them. The two other adults had salads. They said they were good.   I tried the nut roll ale. I enjoyed this holiday beer because of the cinnamon and vanilla. It almost reminded me of root beer. They sell beer to go. I took home a seasonal sampler. $19 for a twelve pack.  My wife isn't into brew pub food. However, I would come back for the beer first and the food second.

l5gXPyhdiVcOElIrWp6rLA.text: first time food was good beer was cold and good wife is a vegaterian they had food for her prices are fair

zA09nlSTfJswkeyBqGxwoQ.text: Food: 2 stars.  Beer: 4 stars.  Service: 3.5 stars.  As an East-Ender I must admit I rarely venture to the North or South Side.  And while I've had many a Penn Brew, I've never made it to their restaurant until last night.  In one word: underwhelmed.  While the building, outdoor seating, and general ambiance were exactly what we were looking for, the food was a huge disappointment.  We were actually pretty excited looking at the menu before we left, but little did we know...   In ordering the Vegetarian Smoked Bratwurst our server all but refused to bring it for me.  He declared it "nasty" and that 50-60% of those ordered end up going back to the kitchen and commenced to try to sell me a garden burger or veggie panini.  I finally gave in and ordered the Pierogi Platter hoping to get something else vegetarian to share with my partner.  I wish I would have ordered the bratwurst.  At first, I was enthused by the serving size but little did I know... what laid before me were 6 dry fish pierogies with a dismissive pile of cold caramelized onions.  I should have sent it back at first bite, but second guessed my own reading of the menu.  When the second pierogi was potato, I decided just to eat them only to find the last 4 to also to be the dry cold fish stuffing.  I didn't eat the last two, we were on a tight schedule and I'm generally too polite to send a mistake like this back.  My partner had the kasespaetzle and while decent, didn't seem True to the spaetzle I've had many times in southern germany.  That said, the beer was quite lovely.  I had the Weizen and my partner the summer berry weizen.  Both well carbonated, flavorful and quite refreshing.  General menu overview: 5-6 apps from $5-8.  A few salads, 6-8 entrees from $9-20 a few sandwiches and a few desserts.

X_YWDswlBtd-negJnL-clw.text: Was in Pittsburgh last week to see family and catch a couple of Pirate games.  A friend recommended the Penn Brewery.  What a great place. Food, beer, service and atmosphere all are an A Plus!!  First night had a dinner with four of my family members at a large communal table.  Had a meat and cheese platter as an app and the Sauerbraten as my entree.  Both delicious and I paired it with a Penn Weizen and two Berliner Weiss (my favorite style).  We all had a great time and as I left filled a growler of Berliner to go.  Next day I returned to refill said growler and have a couple of apps.  Pretzel and stuffed peppers.  Both unreal.  Marie or Maria (sorry) was bartender, she could not have been nicer and even went so far as to ask the brewmaster a couple of questions for me.  Had a nice conversation both nights with a guy named Warren and felt like I was in my local corner bar the whole time.  I look forward to returning and was sorry I missed the Maerzen!! thanks for making our trip so fun!

Eqhhu3sTrXYQVmJZ7SADdg.text: I love restaurants in old buildings, and outdoor seating between the awkward spaces of once was, is always an experience. I felt like I was eating at one of those highly exclusive prison restaurants in Europe. Except I was in Pittsburgh, drinkin' a beer and eatin' some macaroni and cheese a.k.a kase kugle mit speck. I had another side but can't remember what it was. My point is, is that the kase kugle mit speck was just macaroni and cheese. I paid $6.95 for a small macaroni and cheese. At least the Penn Pilsner was worth it, I remember it well. I highly recommend going there for the ambience and beer.

CL72e5WUfYH2PMFIkzWwJg.text: Great beer and the outside area is hopping in the Summertime. Good beer and my sandwich (burger, pulled pork, and french fried onions) were probably the highest caloric intake of 2008. nYocT_yp4RHTZsedhsPB1g.text: While visiting my hometown and family for the holidays I stopped by Penn Brewing to pay my final respects. You may or may not know that after almost 23 years they are shutting it down as a result of raised rents on the space that they occupy which happens to be a century old brewery (the old Eberhart and Ober brewery on the Pittsburgh North Side). If you are interested here is the latest story post-gazette.com/pg/0834... I won't go into it here as it has nothing to do with the review other than if you are interested in their beer, food and atmosphere you better get over there and try it as the official last day of restaurant ops appears to be February 28, 2009. They've brewed the last batch of beer on site as of late November and according to the article above will be dismantling the beautiful brew house. I expect that the last two months will not be up to the standards that we've known for 23 years. Other than my good byes I went to taste their Christmas seasonal the St. Nikolaus Bock. Which lived up to it's long standing standards. Rich, roasty and complex this beer is the perfect pint or liter on a wet, cold winter afternoon. I sat and enjoyed a couple while taking in for the last time the sights and sounds of the beer hall and beautifully displayed brew house. Tom Pastorious (Founder) did a great job of converting this space to an authentic German beer hall complete with the rows of long tables and benches - I don't dare say picnic tables because they aren't. When I walked in yesterday afternoon (December 26th) the place was packed but we elbowed our way to seats at the bar. The crowds just complete the ambience and the feeling of being in an actual German bier hall. We met two strangers at the bar and chatted for a good 30minutes - they were from out of town as well enjoying their final holiday pilgrimage to Penn Brewery. After my first liter I grabbed the menu (being the sucker for German food that I am) knowing what I would find on it having been here numerous times over the years. Lynne and I split the JaegerSchnitzel as an afternoon snack. It was served with a mini loaf of rye bread which was fresh, crunchy on the outside, warm and chewy on the inside and useful for mopping the wonderful mushroom laden sauce that makes this well - Jaeger and not just Viener Schnitzel. A side of mashed potatoes and a side of red cabbage accompanied the schnitzel - both very good. Yes, I'm on a plan next week - tis the season! I've had other dishes here before. The sausages as I recall are very good. If you like/desire German fare and appreciate craft brewed beer this is a great destination. Just as an aside Penn Brewery as they have for years made a showing at the Great American Beer Festival, Penn won two medals: a gold for Kaiser Pils and a bronze for Oktoberfest. I doubt that they will be able to continue this tradition as The Lion will be contract brewing their beers which we all know means the possibly the quality and character can be impacted. Let's keep our fingers crossed that they find a new location and can get back to their artisanal ways! Auf Wiedersehen Penn Brewery! at least and hopefully for a very short period of time.

KfU98ABCKWGzsEs5OvmpRg.text: This place is not what it once was. it is a shell of its self, with outsourced beer production, canned food, and bad service. Sorry to be so negative, it has earned it however.

ovhZlBg5Miw9eEU2_eFWdg.text: I like german food and good German beer. Penn Brewery had both Their Penn Dark is GREAT.

VxD_VNaaJG_tMR4W20h7fQ.text: i remember this place in the days when it was called the allegheny brewery and pub. it is actually called the penn brewery and pub now. the food and beer has stayed the same but the music venue has changed. a great place for german style beer brewed locally in da burgh. food is decent mix of german style foods and american pub classics. best beers are oktoberfest, st niklaus bock, and of course the penn pilsner. back in the day there was a band that played regularly here called the barons, they were the best pub band ever!!! they would start the evening with german folk songs and then their style of polka would get your feet rocking and your palate thirsty for the pilsner. that all warmed you up for the final set of classic 60's dance tunes. nowadays the restaurant has a german violin accordian duo on wednesdays, and solo accordian on saturdays. not the same band but still love that music. definitely can't miss this place on oktoberfest, lively, festive, lots of folk dancing. if you are really into polka, browse polkareview.com they even have one of the barons CDs on their sale list called german sampler.

oy2uhU9ya189L6DVi6GydA.text: Great place for a good German beer.  The Saint Nicholas Bock is one of my favorite seasonal brews. It's a great place to listen to live music and enjoy beer.

mygWDpKhTn7RmZJzZnln6g.text: If you are looking for a Brew Pub with character, then you definitely want to come to Penn Brewery (Hofbrauhaus feels corporate and like it is trying way too hard). I definitely recommend this for dinner, especially when they have musicians.

x6qVgHQFjxXsBs_ZL2aCjQ.text: So, on this trip, wanting to explore True Pittsburgh fare, my friends decided to bring me to the historic Penn Brewery. I'd been curious to sample some Pierogis (Polish Dumplings). I'd tried some in the freezer case back home but found them to be anything but tasty. I was eager to try the real deal. Penn Brewery's ambiance is relaxed and casual with picnic style bench seating and a bar area with TVs. The flies in the relaxed and casual area were incredibly friendly and more than eager to greet you and anything that would soon make it to our table. The persistence was damn near impressive. We were greeted by our server, a blond waitress who seemed polite but a tad distracted. I asked for an order of traditional pierogis to start us off. Mashed potato and cheese tucked in tender dough, sauteed and topped with caramelized onions and sour cream. Yum! Minutes later when she brought our drinks, she  confirmed my order of cheese curds would be out any minute. . After sorting that out and having her answer our questions on different menu items, we ordered. My friends ordered a Braumeister Steak Sandwich, House shaved rib-eye with Penn bier cheese, grilled peppers and onions served on a Breadworks hoagie bun and a Wienerschnitzel Sandwich,Hand breaded pork cutlet, slaw and Heidelberg Dijonnaise on a Breadworks hoagie roll. I, unaware of the oncoming onslaught of blandness and disappointment that would soon befall my tastebuds, ordered the Bier Cheese and macaroni and added grilled chicken to it. Cuz who doesn't love mac n cheese?!   The pierogis made it to the table and with much awaited anticipation i eagerly dug in. Everything that was promised was technically there. Mashed potatoes, greasy dough filled pockets of disappointment covered in sauteed onions and a heap of sour cream. I can't say i could taste any cheese or any semblance of salt to it. Maybe the frozen ones were on point after all? Fortunately, my friends assured me they weren't what they expected either so I guess my hunt for a proper & tasty pierogi is still a thing. lol --but it's definitely not here!   When our food arrived the sandwiches looked amazing and my friends devoured theirs. The pork schnitzel looked fried perfectly and the steak sandwich generous and filling. My plate was a massive heap of curly pasta covered in this epic Bier cheese i wanted to try (cuz -why not?!) and a light dusting of bread crumbs. #omnomnom What could possibly go wrong?!   Well "Bier" (apparently German for bland) cheese on macaroni isn't as tasty as I'd hoped and in hindsight, were it added to a pierogi would've easily blended undetected amidst the sea of saltless treasures. The minimally seasoned chicken breast our fearless server forgot to add wasn't any help either once it arrived late for the party and, not wanting to disappoint my friends who had researched where to find foods to impress, I put on my best tourist smile and made the best of my Velveeta situation. I even insisted on a to go box where the majority of my macaroni ended up. --Never to be seen again...   Not sure if it was an off day for the kitchen or the flavor gods were not in my favor but I definitely would recommend having sandwiches and steering clear of the pierogis and bier cheese in general. Hopefully I'll find pierogis in Pittsburgh to salvage my quest for delicious Polish dumplings  soon enough.

5sDMQBdKlb8pK86j9Uz0fw.text: This review is purely based on a trip to the brewery and the beer. No food was had.  We sat outside and wanted to order a flight but were told we would have to go inside for that. Okay...then I'll just have beer XYZ please. Sorry, we don't serve that beer outside.  Alrighty then, I guess our plan to sit outside on a nice day isn't happening.  So we end up inside sitting at a long table and ordered the flight. It was brought out with no explanation. Most places explain the beers or at least tell you which are which. We had to flag down the waitress to ask her and she stumbled through a little unsure of herself. I think she was wrong on a few of them. Regardless all but the seasonal beer on the flight was flavorless and tasted watered down. The 3 of us in the party all agreed that this was the most disappointing stop on our brewery tour that day. There are much, much better choices around Pittsburgh for my tastes.  That coupled with lackluster service and silly rules for sitting outside pretty much assures that I won't be returning to try the food. 2 stars because the brewery itself looks nice and they do have a nice outdoor area. Apparently we just couldn't use it.

2FF-h7lCbhUnIUqVc1YClQ.text: What a disappointment.  Did not even want to give it a star...This had been my favorite restaurant from the time I moved to Pittsburgh back in 1992.  I have since moved away, but try to make a stop here when visiting.  Last night was an epic failure.  The decor I loved is gone.  Penn Brewery no longer looks like a beer hall in Germany, no colorful banners or authenticity...it looks more like a poorly designed event venue... the only holdovers are the wooden dining tables and long benches.  Even the corner space once home to Oompah bands has been replaced with seating.  We were a group of seven and had a lot of catching up to do, which was enjoyable, but our server was inattentive and absent for the better part of our dinner. There were 2 other servers and maybe 7 other tables with patrons.  Tables were not cleared when patrons left and at one point I saw at least 5 tables covered with dirty dishes.  I am one of those people who likes to order the same thing at "favorite" restaurants.  For me it is starting out with an order of potato pancakes.  Not last night, they were OUT of potato pancakes.  Exactly HOW that happens I don't know.  While I understand there was a festival this past weekend, potato pancakes are a staple of German cuisine, not that tough to make.  I guess that means they don't make them fresh...  On to the roast pork, which I always get with spatzle, instead of potato.  My first clue that something was amiss with my dinner were the bread crumbs on the spatzle...but I went in...eager to taste the slow roasted, tender and juicy pork that so reminded me of my own German grandmother's cooking.  Nope...not to be...instead what I had on my plate were 4 slices of what can only be described as someone's 3 days old leftover pork loin cover in tasteless gravy.  I even tried a piece of each slice just to be sure, but it all had the telltale taste of meat left too long in the fridge.  On to the spatzle...now I've made this at home - not tough... batter, a sieve to press it through and boiling water;  drain and swish those delightful little guys in a pan of butter and voila!  Nope...on MY plate was a haphazard group of odd shaped carb bombs. Many resembling some alien form of pasta.  They were over seasoned with something... like thyme?  And then there were the bread crumbs....a fellow diner actually commented that my plate looks like Thanksgiving gone wrong...I will say the green beans were fresh and done to perfection.  Why didn't I send my dinner back you say??  Well, I would have if our server had seen fit to check in on us.  Even when she DID return with our checks she never asked how everything had been, nor did she ask me about my obviously mostly-full plate; she did not even offer me a box to take my leftovers home, which I would have kindly refused.    Honestly this meal was so bad I did not even want to waste more of my valuable "friend" time to speak to a manager.  It is obvious that changes made need to be re-evaluated.  The Help Wanted signs on the entrance door should have been my first clue.    Come to Penn Brewery for the beer - the outdoor courtyard area is beautiful and thankfully the beer is still good.

zZBj8ugliTLXE8Im4aDmuQ.text: Love penn brewery!! Came for the Deutschland music festival and it was super busy but Kaithlynn was such an amazing waitress!! Very friendly and attentive!! Always was there when we needed her. Would definitely return!!

qwERvrIMlHgL5qawMWFbwg.text: Food is okay. I have had a few different things off the menu and nothing really impressed me. The wings are good and so is the Greek salad. The 2 star review is due to their service. EVERYTIME I order and that is no exaggeration everytime something is wrong with my order. Also the food takes forever to come out. I work in the Northside so I think the only reason I continue to come back is due to convenience of location and co workers. We have an hour lunch and we call a half and hour before coming over just to make sure our food comes out a half hour after we get there. there have been times we have sat, ordered and had to get our food Togo because it took almost an hour to come out. Staff is overall friendly but could be more attentive.

CwKhWDclpLSt1HFzFeFsOw.text: I've been to Penn Brewery more times than I'll admit, so I can confidently compose a fair and thorough review.  Ranked simply on the beer, the Brewery would easily earn 5 stars. The "Gold" and "Pilsner" are consistently delicious and award-winning. Both have been recognized by national reviewers. The Brewery has added quite a few seasonal beers to its menu, though the two above stand out. Depending on the season, the Oktoberfest and St. Nick's Bock are also worth it.  Penn Brewery's food does not score as highly, mainly due to a lack of consistency and quality. Some items are always good: the pretzels & bier cheese, the potato pancakes, and the appetizer flat-breads are excellent (especially if they are available at happy hour prices).   The chili ($6 for a bowl) is big enough to be ordered as a meal and delicious and the goulash is comforting on a cold day.   The sandwiches and entrees, however, are hit or miss. Some of the lunch meat (especially the turkey) is only okay and the presentation/taste fluctuate. The meat entrees also vary in size depending on the visit. Overall, I give 3.5 stars on the food, though I mainly order the things I know will be good.  Execution at the Brewery could be stronger. For example, although the employees are kind and attentive, they seem to lack a strong grasp of the restaurant's menu and happy hour, which has changed frequently.  Additionally, the check-in process near the bar area creates a congested and chaotic atmosphere. The Brewery is styled after a German beer house, but there is no strong plan for funneling people when they are waiting to be sat. On busy nights, it is not uncommon to eat food with a person standing above your plate.   Also, the beer - although great! - is not always available. I've been to Penn Brewery twice this summer and the Penn Gold beer was not available either time. How a brewery runs out of its flagship beer during the summer months is beyond me and if I owned the joint, I'd do everything in my power to ensure it never happened.  Lastly, I have to include mention of the Brewery's beer garden, which sits between the Brewery and a historic warehouse. Simply put, the garden is one of the coolest places to sit and enjoy some great beer. At times, there is live music, which makes the experience even more fun.   Thanks for reading!

bv2jn0Yeo-eS83BOqhIPyg.text: Great selection of German style beers! Located in a very old brick building with an upstairs and a downstairs. The upstairs had a great view of the brewery (brew action) tabled and chairs and a big bar. The downstairs looked like it was for a private event or large parties. Only stopped here for a beer but next time I would love to try the German food here! Service was great! Even got a tshirt!

1lLFy9TOBqcPhRO9iJvEsQ.text: I'm giving Penn Brewery a solid four stars. Stopped in for dinner and a beer and I wasn't disappointed.   We started off with the cheese and brews. We decided to go with the five cheese and five beer sampler. The cheese is really good! Everyone had an opinion on which beer was the best ( I said the penn weizen) so I'll let you decide which is the best choice. I had the bier cheese and macaroni for the main entree. It was delicious. I added the sausage to it and I'm glad I did because it was good. My wife had the rabbit and she liked it, but said she would probably try something different next time.  The beer was cold and the food was good. The service was quick and friendly. The inside setup is kind of odd but I guess it works. The stairs were roped off and you had to use the elevator to go downstairs to use the bathroom. Not a big deal, just odd because it's usually the other way around.   Anyways, I had a good experience here and will be back again. Most certainly recommend.

AjbfI3fR-d-W_C8fSrfg0g.text: I am visiting Pittsburgh with my dog and called ahead to see if the restaurant was dog friendly, something I always do before heading to a restaurant.   The person who answered the phone said dogs are welcome, but had to sit on the edge of the courtyard and informed me they had a special doggy dining area near the gates with a grass area and tables. I asked if we would be able to order food, I was informed it was full service. Sounded great, so we headed to Penn Brewery for dinner.   Upon arrival, I discovered that the "special area" was an area about 10 feet outside of the restaurant courtyard gates with a sign designating it as the dog area where they would move a table for you. It was also next to a frontage road and adjacent to the freeway, which is not ideal for dining or conversation. I asked if there was anyway to sit on the outside of the other gate, the staff kindly accommodated my request.   Be prepared to not really dine in the outdoor restaurant area, but rather beyond the gates. The staff explained this is a state regulation they must follow, which I understand. However, I wish that the description on the phone would've been more accurate. Also this was not our first dog dining experience of this trip, but the first time we ran into such an awkward seating situation. As someone visiting from a very dog friendly area it would've been nice to know that if you want to bring your dog, you won't be getting the full restaurant experience, since the dog isn't allowed in the actual restaurant outdoor area.  Overall the staff was friendly and accommodating. They moved a table for us, they apologized and said they would pass along my note about the inaccurate phone description. However, I would opt for another restaurant if you want to dine with your pup with a less awkward sitting arrangement.

k40kdV9SdZy6SLn9DwuJXg.text: Given the mixed reviews, I wasn't quite sure to what to expect when I came here recently. And fittingly, I'd say my experience was mixed, although overall positive.  We went on a Saturday evening, and I thought the place would be hopping, but it was sort of dead. The space is beautiful though, and it was a shame that their charming courtyard beer garden was not being patronized by more people that evening. We were seated indoors in their downstairs area, which was cozy, but a bit dark and dungeon-like. The evening started off on an annoying note when it took about 15 minutes for a waiter to come by and take our drink order (though he was more attentive after that).  Our waiter was hilariously blunt. Several times when we tried to order something, he shot us down with his unsolicited (though actually appreciated) opinion:  Us: "We'll try the mussels to start." Waiter (with horrifying look): "No, you don't want to order those. They are really sandy." Us: "Umm, ok, thanks for the heads up. How about the peanut butter and jelly wings?" Waiter (gives knowing glance): "How do you THINK wings with peanut butter and jelly would taste? Don't get those."  Later for our meal order:  Friend: "I'll have the rabbit for dinner." Waiter (same horrifying look as before): "No, no good. Literally ANYTHING else would be a better choice."  Though it was a bit odd, we did appreciate his candor about the food and I know he was just trying to be helpful. Also it gave us plenty to giggle about every time he left the table.  Anyway, speaking of the food, waiter man's tips were fairly solid, because we were pleased with almost everything we ordered. To start, we sampled the Black BBQ wings, which were meaty, juicy, and crispy. We also tried the pierogies, which were good, though nothing noteworthy (I can think of about a dozen places off of the top of my head that serve a better pierogie). On the annoying side, they only gave 3 pierogies in the appetizer serving, which for $7 bucks seems a little stingy. Also, 3 is an odd number of anything for an appetizer, as most dining parties are 2 or 4 people (ours was 4). Thanks for creating an awkward sharing situation, Penn Brewery. Anyhow, we also tried the pretzel and bier cheese, which everyone at the table liked except for yours truly (I found the stiff mousse-y texture of the cheese to be unappetizing).  For our meal, my husband and I split the chicken kasespaetzle, which appears to be Germany's answer to mac n' cheese. It was really tasty, with a rich, creamy, tangy and flavorful sauce, plenty of juicy chicken, and tender pasta dumplings. Our friends split the roasted pork, which they reported to be delicious as well. Entree portions were generous and more than enough for us to split and still feel full and happy (especially given the appetizers we had). For dessert, we shared the apple strudel, and our waiter was quite pleased.  "GREAT choice, that's the best dessert we have!" he exclaimed a little too enthusiastically after we ordered it.   Thanks, waiter, glad we finally could nail it on the first try. And nail it we did -- the strudel was heavenly. Flaky pastry crust and warm, soft apple filling paired with melty vanilla ice cream was the perfect way to end our meal. Very good experience overall. Or should I say, "sehr gut" experience overall.

SM0sk7HX1PprtGarvLJ1jg.text: I started coming her monthly, years before moving to Pittsburgh,so it's 20 years I've been eating here.  I bought a Groupon, and treated my daughter to  dinner for a GNO.  I was the designated driver, and ordered water (I don't drink soda).  Janelle, the server, didn't hide her disappointment at no big bar tab. The service she gave us was abysmal, at best. She took our orders, brought us drinks, and the check. A food runner seved us dinners and dessert. The sausage on my sausage platter($18) was barely warm, though my daughter's mac and bier cheese ($14) was piping hot.  My sauerkraut was piping hot,  the German potato salad warm, and both were delicious. The Apfel Strrudel for dessert was barely warm, and dough a bit stiff. It needed more cinnamon, too. I dropped my knife during dinner, and had to hunt someone down for a replacement. Janelle didn't know how to process a Groupon, and 3 people later, I finally got a shift manager who did,and she took dessert off the bill. ($7) She apologized and said she hoped I would return. Even though I told her about my 20 year patronage, and that this was a treat for my daughter, she gave no incentive to return. So, I won't. I may call the GM and give him a chance, to be fair.

suSdUnlXbasQMtH7MYcevA.text: Stopped in on a Sunday afternoon and we were one of just a few tables sitting outside. Sometimes during slow periods, servers can forget about you, but we had great service from start to finish.   We had the fried pickles as an appetizer and loved ones the aioli sauce that accompanied them. For our main course we split the Bier Mac n Cheese and oh-my-god was it delicious. Really rich. My husband is a native German and Penn Brewery is definitely somewhere to head if you're craving good German grub.   Can't end a review without mentioning their beer selection- it is great!

aMRVj6Aa7zLQyxAXAbh9Zw.text: Awesome food. Great atmosphere. Good prices. Friendly staff. All around winner. I got a Reuben and my girlfriend got a burger.  Both were fantastic my girlfriend loved the craft beer. Bartender was very polite

cPnodQKGhljcInNh4mmuqA.text: I was very disappointed in my steak last night. Over half of it was fat and I could not even eat it. Again the beer is awesome. Next time I will not order a meal and just get pretzels or another appetizer. Also, my companions did not really care for their food either.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Steak (majority of it was fat) :(

8KWkg5BUHxVI6NEbRrctMQ.text: Review #911! Call a medic!!! A cop!!!! youtube.com/watch?v=lxk_... After visiting PB months ago for our lone Yelp Elite Event to date, Kay and I knew we had to return, especially being that today was a payday Friday and that PB is minutes from where I work. . A gothic courtyard featuring caged crannies that look as if they were designed to hold dragons leads to a staircase entry into the establishment. There is another way to get inside from the street, but I prefer to go take the cobblestone detour since it's Victorian looking and therefore wickedly cool to me. My heroic, fantastical imagination allows me to conceptualize a moonlit, midnight clash with a ghoul, vampire, or some other such creature of the shadows here. The interiors are jolly and anything but creepy. People holding frothy, wet mugs of housebrewed mead amidst the brass and copper pipes and tanks from which it flows. Communal, stained, wooden benches and tables are where patrons seat themselves. I knew I wanted some pierogi, so I pretty much disregarded the rest of the menu and settled on the Pierogi Platter, a hexad of dough parcels containing potatoes and cheese with grilled onions as a sweet garnish. Our bubbly, talkative server Amanda knows what the score is. When I asked for sour cream on the side minutes after placing my order, she said, "Dude, you're covered. Who eats pierogi without sour cream anyway? That's not right." And out they came, quickly. In fact, our appetizer, salads, my chili, and our entrees came out simultaneously, almost overwhelming us. Some people might have found this to be a misstep of service, but I barely minded. I mean, before I could get impatient, a feast was abruptly placed before me! Good food fast? You bet your hiphuggers...hipster. Well, for the most part at least. Everything was comfortably comestible, and that includes my house viniagrette salad, even if the dressing was unduly syrupy but only a touch so. Our starter was a spreadably splendid wedding between Sharp Cheddar and Cream Cheese that was blessed by Penn Pilsner and overseen by average, dried-out, mall-grade pretzels. I would have rather had the spread, which tasted like a far more intelligent and gourmet kind of spray cheese, on some crackers instead. A cup of their Penn Pilsner Chili was next on deck. Freshly ground chuck, kidney beans, and black beans made for fine, hearty, tomato-based spoonfuls of sweetly fermented and profoundly satisfying stew. Hey, I may not drink beer or any other kinds of booze, but if you put it in some excellent food, I'll board the boat to Margaritaville without delay. Oh, the pierogi; they were peerless. The outer dough was caramelized, took on the flavors of the onions, and contained the most luscious mashed potatoes ever to be served at your favorite aunt's house. As someone whose blood is mostly Polish, I was proud of these paradisiac pierogi and was greatly gladdened that a chef had come up with a proper recipe for them. Kay had the Rouladen, a fragile, sultry, enlivened, and rolled-up carpet of steak, bacon, onions, and pickles that was coated with a deeply savorous, beer-borne, and cryptic "brown sauce." Dessert (they only have a Warm Apple Strudel and Chocolate Raspberry Cake on tap) we skipped due to having a surplus of treats at home, but please do not skip Penn Brewery. If a teetotaler like myself had a pleasurable dinner here, you should as well.

heNnRCQTHlw9k9kVYf86Zw.text: Enjoyed the sampler of the 10 beers they had on tap. Butcher's Plate was okay. Potato Pancakes a win. Sat a the bar. Se vic could have been better/more attentive, especially considering howany staff members were on the clock for a not very busy night.

-mJG59x5l0Mj935Luq1g3g.text: Lived in Pittsburgh all my life can't believe this was my first time here.  There German style food is outrageous good.  I had the sausage platter with sour kraut and some kind of German potatoes.  All the sausages were very good dipped in a little mustard, sour kraut amazing!!!!  The potatoes were bad but I didn't care cause the rest of the plate was so stellar.  The spatzle with mushroom sauce was also outstanding with grill chicken.  There Pilsner beers are ok and I really likes the wiezen.  Can't wait to go back though for the food!!  Prices are a little steep but not bad.

PD356q1MKtdkkBOZAULZmA.text: Legit Oktberfest brew and one of the best brats I've had- ever. (Bonus: staff were using Murphy's Oil Soap to clean all of the nice wood in the place - the only way to take care of your finest wood pieces.) Great spot!

2hCIrtYwLz6UweXcUjZWnw.text: Came here with a coworker and let me say I love the look of the place- has a beautiful courtyard and the inside definitely sells an old look but is pleasing to look at.   The inside was clean and the waiters/tenders were attentive. Drinks are very good, I tried multiple and do not think there was one I would not drink again- absolutely delicious.   Food was pretty good- the pretzel was tasty- a little salty but I enjoyed it still- most people love the salt- I go easy on it. The cheese dip was perfect though- the kind that makes you close your eyes and savor the moment when you bite into it.   I got the cheesesteak- it was okay, nothing to brag about, but was decent.   I will definitely come back. But the highlight of this place is the liquids not the solids.

JR4MO5kWg2gI_Eu_y0gQdA.text: Excellent place to visit when in Pittsburgh! Beautiful place, great service, and an excellent selection of beers.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

mkPzQ5n5UU7z4wIOudDkYA.text: Great service, beer, food & tour!   I had the 10 beer sampler.  Our waitress here, Dawn brought out a couple of additional tastes...personal favorites of hers and other staff. NICE!  We tried the basket: pretzels, beer cheese, beer battered chicken strips and honey mustard dip.  that fed two of us just fine!  Then Dawn introduced us to Dave who I believe to be a brewer.  Dave gave us a quick tour of the place and broke down some history of the establishment and the hill it sits on.  He was great.  He can read the bewilderment on your face and dumb the tour down or kick it up to geek level and answer technical questions from beer nerds or the weekend afficionado.  Best PIT-stop yet on my weekend visit to Pittsburgh.

CSsHi1_7LdExVjTTJSmgWw.text: Best Hefeweizen and Fried Cheese curds ever!  So the Penn Weizen beer here is phenomenal. Light but flavorful and just a very refreshing beer.  The winner here is the fried cheese curds. I was blown out of the water with how great these darn things were! The batter/breading was VERY light but VERY crunchy and salty which was amazing. The cheese curds themselves were squeaky, melted and oooooooooo soooooo good.  Were also ordered the Sweet Sriracha Wings and Pomme-Frites. The Pomme-Frites (Fries with chili, bacon, sour cream, cheese and scallions) were disappointing. THey were smothered which was good but bad. The fries turned to mush (did not hold up to the chili) but the chili was decent, not great, but decent.  The Wings, ehhhh I've had better and for the price I wouldn't get them again. The wings weren't that big in size and the sauce, while okay, needed a bit more sauce. When i hear sriracha I expect to be punched in the mouth a bit lol, more sweet than spice.  Overall though, I'd stop in for the beer and curds any day which is why this place gets 5 stars, after all they are a brewery!

FTkiPNv4kWbRUttgxU9mSw.text: I've given this place 3 tries. Each time hoping that I'm going to like it as the outside space and ambiance tells me I should. I just can't get past the mediocre food and choices of beer.   I've said before I'm not a beer drinker. But I usually find something, except here.   This was another stop on the brew tour I took my brother on while he visited. Even he, as a beer lover, didn't even want to try anything that was offered.  That's all for me. I won't try again.

GpcaZheJb1cf_Wkuyj2bag.text: I went with my sister last week. Sorry for a late review!  I enjoy the potato pancakes!  The use there own apple sauce and sour cream concoction.  The pancakes a thick and full of potatoes!! Everything together was awesome!  The portions are huge.  They're each the size of a saucer plate. If you get a opportunity to visit Penn Brewery.., try the potatoes!

KvgxJPXTQuY3tnM8GdltHQ.text: Great local brewery.  This year's Oktoberfest brew is top notch!

pqGAyMQ0pjcS9qkU3QexHw.text: We visited Penn Brewery on a weekend evening, there were 5 of us.   The building itself is clearly old, but has been kept really well and didn't have that can't-get-the-dirt-off feel to it. There was casual seating, a nice bar up top, and quieter, cozier seating down the stairs near the beer. It definitely still had the feel of a brewery!  Everybody was happy with their food, and liked the beer as well. Personally I had some of the sausage stuffed peppers (so good, and gluten free! it's so rare to see GF stuffed peppers) and a bunless burger with fries. Everything was delicious.   We had a little snafu with our seating when we arrived, but it was made up to us in spades with a few free beers!!! I was pleased to see that the place puts their customers first and could sense we were a little uncomfortable. It made the night a lot better.   I would return if I lived in the area!

Xg4b3hmFfBFVnv7-uxmzRA.text: Beer sampler flight - take the whole 10.  It is rare (unlike my husband)  that I can go through 10 different beers and go , yeah - I like that..  AND 4 beers that were so good they actually forced my eyeballs to the back of my head.  Weizen - a wheat with banana undertones, Chocolate Stout - a collaboration with a local chocolate artisan, Nut Bowl- served with sugared rim glass, flavored with yumminess and their St. Nick Reserve.  Their Penn Gold and Dark rocked - close eyes - think Octoberfest in Munich.  Even their hoppier pilsners were really well balanced.  Food, service, band, locale - perfect.  The brats were wonderful.  Good chili.  Fresh salad.  Gluten Free menu offerings were clearly indicated.    Is a manager reading?  Offer cider or a Gluten Free Beer alternate as well as a GF dessert choice.   I love you Penn Brewery!

Vfs72PtwirhlShVxWNiX2g.text: The music was pretty loud for a Sunday dinner. The staff was friendly and inviting. I had the philly "cheesesteak" and the red cabbage. I really liked the portobello mushrooms. The cheese is a little messy so it is definitely a fork sandwich. The red cabbage was excellent. Slightly sweet and tart.

neIGWdZdYPqYkJz5KO0I-A.text: My partner and I were drawn here because of the European brews they have on offer but we weren't blown away by the tasting room or the beer. The place is out of the way for walkers staying in the city and it was completely empty when we arrived. The staff seemed bored and disinterested in helping us pick a beer and they mostly kept to themselves by the bar. The beers themselves were average and I don't think I would ever seek it out again. Overall, this place is good to go to once but I wouldn't go back.

fj2ONc3JElag7V7d2tHgSQ.text: Favorite brewery in Pittsburgh. Their year-round beer selection is tasty, and seasonal beers are even better. (Don't pass up the Nut Roll Ale in wintertime.)  I tried a Moscow Mule with their housemade Hot Ginger beer.  It was average; not much flavor.  I'll stick with their beer in the future.   What really makes Penn Brew stick out is their fantastic food menu.  I dreamt about their Pierogis my entire drive from Cincinnati.  Do NOT pass these up. We also tried the pretzel sticks and BBQ chicken flatbread this time as well; I would get both again.  The pretzel sticks are served with three unique dips, all German and made in house.  The cheese dip is to die for.     For whatever reason, their menu is loaded with vegetarian option.  If that is your preferred diet, this is the place for you.

uu0xpkoUgq8hs_ZLIx7DkA.text: I cannot express my love for this place in words. The atmosphere is awesome. Being seated outside or inside is always a treat. The place holds history and looks so eclectic. The food is even better. Everything is German themed and they have things on their menu you'd never find elsewhere. Their burgers are out of this world! As is anything else i've tried there. This place is a Pittsburgh staple and definitely a must try for those visiting the city. I'll miss it when I move! Thank you Penn Brewery!

2UWgA2EgM40cAR_YhL7Jkw.text: I've been frequenting the Penn Brewery on and off since the early 90's.  It's been many years since I've reviewed, but I've given multiple 5 star reviews in the past.  It's been one of my favorite places.  I love their beer, particularly Penn Pilsner, Penn Dark, St. Nicholas Bock, and the Marzen. They are staples at my home year-round. I'm no fan of the novelty beers such as Chocolate Meltdown and Nut Roll Ale but I understand this is for a greater mass appeal, nor is beer the subject of this review.  A group of us stopped here recently and I was unexpectedly, and highly disappointed. I think I need to give German style food a break as the tug-of-war between being so-called "authentic" vs. taste vs. price just doesn't seem to be worth it to me anymore. We found that the portion sizes on this visit were absurdly inadequate. One person in my party received about a tablespoon of sauerkraut while my portion was more like a cup (as expected, but still lacking for the high price).  However, the biggest complaint was related to what we received from the Appetizer and A La Carte portion of the menu:  The buffalo wings were $9 for 6 wing-dings (half wings). Do the math and you'll see that this comes out to $36 per dozen. Okay, I get it... it's not a wing place, but worse yet was the quality! These were the equivalent of the supermarket frozen boxed Tyson or TGI Friday's wings that are cooked in the microwave or under the broiler. They were slimy, rubbery and barely edible. There was a negligible amount of buffalo sauce on them.  Dear Penn Brewery: If you don't want to serve wings, please pull them off of the menu. These were disgusting!!! Take some PRIDE in what you serve!   The Brussel sprouts were $6 ala carte simply because it had the word "porchetta" attached to it. There was nothing "porchetta" about them. They tasted okay with the bacon undertones, but wow what a travesty on quality vs. price. For me, the wings alone were enough to put the chef (or line cook) on probation. We took our lumps, didn't complain and left a big tip (the server was great), but it's going to be a long time before I come back here and when we do we'll stick with a pizza or a burger and leave the German Food for home cooking.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Think this plate is worth $17? Neither do I!!! Again the &#34;heat lamp&#34; style wings not pictured.
Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Not bad but certainly not worth $18. The &#34;microwave&#34; quality wings are not pictured.

KoiQjZdMiaGJeDF04CKudg.text: I love Penn Brewery! If you are a lover of German foods and beers then you will love it too! The brewery is in a cool historic building filled with long wooden tables and a window where you can see the beer being made. Totally great photo op right when you get there with the old light up sign outside! I highly recommend getting the butcher plate appetizer, it's a little pricey but totally worth it.  My other food recommendations are the potato pancakes and pierogies! Just order them, you will not be sorry.  As for drinks, I love the Penn Weizen but if you're not sure what to get or want to try a bunch get the sampler! With the beer sampler they give you really good size pours and it's a pretty good price.  Also if you are considering trying Penn Brewery, always check Groupon first!  I was able to get a really good deal on their amazing food with a Groupon. Penn Brewery is a great place to stop for apps, dinner, drinks or all 3!

SU5G8kM6tCcYIiM0BG6Ypg.text: Well, happens to the best places.  It used to be a great place.  Good beer and food.  Now the food is poor, just barely warm, soggy fries, and takes a long time.  Beer is still good.  Forget the food.  Not sure what happened but they dropped the ball somewhere along the way and never picked it up again.

plb4p4EM5vKgDeA01-o9sw.text: I am a very big fan of the atmosphere, the history that this place has, and the beer, however I am not a big fan of the food. Everything came out very greasy, my fiance ordered the steak salad medium well done but this most recent time, it came out chewy and well under cooked, it was sent back and remade....came out just as chewy.  Other than that, the food is usually very good especially their German entrees and sandwiches.  Side Note: If you have every been here before and seen the 3 person bar....yeah that is not a nice horseshoe bar with ample seating.

LuyUgUWdqXl_YARYqgYsQw.text: Terrific German recipe beers, particularly the World renowned, World Cup winning Penn Gold, a helles style lager. Tasty selection of German and Pittsburgh American food, all in an historic location.

BUpo61NHgXEMdgbs1FN3pQ.text: I had the Buffalo Chicken pierogi for my lunch today paired with a delicious, small-batched New England IPA called Toxic Lupulinity. Both were fantastic!! The pierogi were a perfect mix of crispy and savory. My daughter enjoys the chicken fingers and kids burgers as well!! Every Tuesday, kids eat free with a purchase of an adult entree. This place is everything we could have hoped for in a local, family-friendly brewery!

lsFB9USTmmHuoUuqH1X94Q.text: Penn Brewery isn't only a cool place to grab a cold beer, they also serve some very tasty food.   We came here on a Saturday in September to celebrate Oktoberfest.  We were a little early so we missed the bands that played later in the day, but we still got to enjoy the beer and food for the occasion.  We decided to go with a quart of Oktoberfest beer to share.  Fall beers are amongst some of my favorite alcoholic delights.  Penn Brewery makes a mighty tasty Oktoberfest-style beer.  To go along with that we split an order of traditional potato and cheese pierogi, and a sausage platter that had three different types of sausages with sauerkraut and a German hot potato salad.  While we waited for our food we enjoyed the outdoor biergarten, which is pet friendly and spacious.    Our food was delivered and it was a nice portion so splitting it worked out great.  We came with my little brother and his girlfriend and they both ordered the fish sandwich, which in hindsight they could have split one since neither finished their sandwiches.  In other words, expect large portions.  The sausages were great dipped in some mustard.   I also enjoyed the pierogis and sauerkraut but totally could pass on the potato salad.   Way too sweet for my liking.  Overall great place to hang with friends or family and share a beer and some good German style grub.
