CUqBBLM-XpOsMRlcvCKWOg.text: The food was incredible!! The IPA was pretty hoppy but still drinkable. The only thing I was disappointed with was the service. We were very neglected and had like 3 different servers, plus our food came out warm not hot. So it was probably forgot about. Will probably go again but will definitely be sitting at the bar

yuLPWsmKys-FgNfqQXF7wA.text: My husband and I are enjoying our first visit to Pittsburgh on a self-designed baseball tour. After going to a Pirates game, I scanned Yelp for restaurants in our hotel area and found Penn Brewery. We love German food and beer so decided to try it on a Thursday evening. We were very happy with all of our beer and food choices. Our server, Rachel, was friendly, efficient, and helpful in making choices. We ordered traditional pierogies to start, jagerschnitzel and the sausage platter as entrees. We ordered the dark and marzen beers to start. Later we got a flight to try others, all brewed on site. Prices are very reasonable and portions generous. We were too full to order dessert so will have to return.

gnred-Hempur_FBRt8nIzQ.text: Lots of good stuff but there are a few stinkers on the menu as well. We loved the poutine and the Jeagerschnitzel, but the French dip was awful. The fat was not rendered, and it was oddly spiced (cumin maybe?). In any case, whatever it was did not complement the rest of the sandwich in my opinion.  It was also offensively noisy, but not in the good way that often is to be expected at a crowded Biergarten. Tonight it was almost empty but there was some amplified speaking coming from elsewhere in the building. Maybe trivia, but definitely annoying and incomprehensible. If we come back, we will try for a night without that type of event and remember to steer clear of the French dip.

1M7_B9T7WgxCyORjWjxcLw.text: Great food, great beer, great staff! I've visited Penn Brewery regularly for years, don't think I'll ever get sick of it. I'm neither a foodie or beer connoisseur, so I can't & won't speak in those terms. I can simply say that this place always satisfies. My favorite beers are Penn Weizen (mmm...bananas), Chocolate Meltdown (ahh...Betsy Ann Chocolate) & Hot Ginger (well, when I could get it. Don't know if they'll brew that again, but I REALLY hope so). My favorite food at Penn - Cheese Curds, German Reuben & Fish Sammich. Always a great atmosphere, inside the Bier Hall or outside in the Bier Garden. Love it when I can catch live music there, but not sure that happens too often anymore. The waitstaff & bartenders are top-notch, friendly folks - never a bad vibe here. I feel so freakin spoiled having Penn Brewery as my neighborhood watering hole!

hVOISw5FEOyn3F1pH369cA.text: Food was delicious and so was the beer. Only gripe was that the restrooms were very dirty and looked as though they hadn't been cleaned in a while.

VLt2mli6huN-KScAsKtYrA.text: First, let me say that we have been going to Octoberfest since it started there. We recently attended this year. When we got there, it looked like the usual crowd having a good time everywhere. We went into the big hall to have dinner, put our names in and was told it would be AN HOUR wait. I looked around the hall where there were no less than 10 tables with disbelief. I said "Ok" and we sat over near the bar at a hightop table. The waitress stops over and takes our Octoberfest beverage order. She brings that and we ask if we can order some appetizers. Normal request, right? She says since we're waiting on a table we can't order apps. Huh? We ask why and she says the kitchen can't handle any orders. What? So, my wife asks the bartender and he takes our order for apps. The waitress stops back and apologizes. I asked her what the big deal was and she said that since they opened the bottle shop the kitchen was MADE SMALLER. Seriously? One thing you don't need at Octoberfest is a smaller kitchen. Plus, the hall wasn't decorated in the usual German motif.  Unfortunately, in an effort to improve something, they've totally ruined a once unique event in Pittsburgh. Sorry, Penn Brewery...I'm taking my business elsewhere.

qTpJiv0WBEfycNO11ZXzHw.text: Penn Brewery tries really hard to be an atmospheric bar, good for family occasions as well as nightly celebrations.  They surely accomplish that with more than decent service from on-point servers.  Their beer is absolutely fine like most everything else they serve.    However, I can't help but feel some menu items clearly need worked on.  I've been to Germany and had Turkish Doner Kebab and moreover I work at a Mediterranean restaurant where we serve gyro, but this Doner at Penn Brewery just looked and tasted sad.  The meat cracked off from what it seemed to be old dry "gyro".  I should have sent it back.    Though my family had an INCREDIBLE baked Italian sub and I couldn't help but feel slighted in the sheer effort that went into that.  The Spatzle was good, Reuben did fine, etc.    Overall the brewery does a generally incredible job with most everything, there is room for improvement.

BY0iWpIJ8y_pEfCQ2VfNNQ.text: Bartender wasn't very friendly. The beer was cold, and delicious! Had some poutine to go along with it. All in all, was a great place with great beer, and food!

vctQ9gIWR5U8lYf2y8HrQw.text: This place is so cool and has great beer! But. For some strange reason the refused to serve any sort of food outside from 2-5 for us yet they served others outside. All we wanted were some pretzels.

7FMcqsIj62uoyp0B3x3uJg.text: I went here a couple times for this years Oktoberfest.  Even though it was raining and chilly there was a huge turn out of people as well as a huge parking nightmare.  If you go on a Sunday you definitely miss the traffic, but you also miss the wall-to-wall people, so whichever is your preference.  (Although the poorly maintained parking lot almost knocked off part of my car).  I did enjoy the crowded beer drinking atmosphere, and they even had extra porta-poties for the masses.  If you prefer the great indoors, the women's bathroom was in a shambles, but well impressively maintained for the constant line of 10 people for hours and hours.    The Oktoberfest beer was great, and $15 for a half gallon was great for sharing.  I also had their dark beer which didn't impress me as much as I expected, but was still drinkable.   The food was very German and very tasty.  Three of us had an appetizer platter, and 3 main courses, I got the 'Wurst Platte', and with a round or so of beers the total was around $100.  The sharp taste of the meats and pickles paired well with the beer.   The outside was a great place to drink and hang out with friends, albeit loud and occasionally a bit too close for comfort on a Friday, but quite tranquil and family friendly on Sunday.  The inside was full of warm wood,serenades  from men in lederhosen, and a view to the brewtanks.

LaRznSMi5rVO6fklaVctBQ.text: VERY IMPRESSED! I bought a groupon earlier this year and we decided to give it a try. The food was awesome and authentic. I also ordered a Penn Dark beer and it quickly became my favorite dark beer. It was a great experience and I intend to go back soon. Highly recommended.

M6JXshLSphgf_oV95TwxyQ.text: First stop from the airport was Penn Brewery. My bestie McGee is a big brewpub fan, and he had been planning to bring me here since he discovered it upon his moving to the North Side.  It's a great place! Any spot where you can saddle up to the bar and strike up a conversation with locals, get to know the story behind the place, sample some local specialties- the appeal factor for me is unforgettable. The staff were a friendly bunch, all happy to share suggestions and let me sample some seasonal offerings. The food did not disappoint either. We had Pierogis (Polish dumplings) and Potato Pancake to share. Pierogis are not a typical West Coast specialty, so in my humble opinion, all I can say is they were good, and went well with the beer.  I'd say this place is good for an out of towner looking for some direction on what local brews are worth your time. Even though we sampled some smaller bits from the menu, I'd also venture to say the mains are probably worth a shot too.  I am sure I'll be back at the Penn Brewery just as soon as I breeze back through my favorite drinking city on the map.

b_hlPa3FWDfkSeSLvzh1Wg.text: The beer is good; the food is terrible (except for the potato pancakes, which were very tasty.). The Buffalo chicken dip tasted like grounded up chicken gizzards and was almost blackened on top from being in the broiler too long. The fish was over-fried, dry and tasteless. The sauerbraten resembled beef stew, not really German sauerbraten. There were six people in our party and every one of them were disappointed. We used to go there years ago when the food was authentic, but now it's just your typical, over-fried bar food. We will not be back.

G5RYRVSQNMWyiMwBz87H6g.text: The food and the beer were good, the service was ok, and the restaurant itself looked, smelled, and sounded like an oversized bar. There was live music there and even before they started, the people downstairs were very loud...to the point we couldn't hear each other across the table.

lXsGWH0f6ZpTseb-I9iVXg.text: Love their Oktoberfest and Penn Dark, unfortunately service wasn't the best and the Pittsburgh salad was just ok.  Should have known their french fries wouldn't have been up to par considering it's a German Restaurant.  The pretzels were amazing though.  A few years back I went for Oktoberfest and a brewery tour. Great tour, great band, and of course, great beer!

h4dSeDrsnd45937IOm9jlA.text: Yes, their Oktoberfest is, by far, one of the best outdoor celebrations in Pittsburgh.  But if it is sadly not September, there is still a reason to cross the river to the North Side. It is called happy hour.   Honestly, things were better before the new drink tax--somehow, a 10 percent tax resulted in nearly a 17 percent price increase. But, regardless, I can't stop going. Every Monday - Thursday, from 5 - 7PM, there are specials.   While the website still says that you can get at 22 oz. Penn Weizen on Wednesdays ("Weizen Wednesday!"), the last time we were there, we were charged $3.50.   If you're not looking to spend a lot of money, but still want something to eat, an order of Goulash and a side of bread is enough to feed at least three people. Think of it as a gourmet chips and dip.   Perhaps the best part, however, is the entertainment. Where else can you watch grown men in lederhosen play music and sing while you drink a huge beer?  Until I came here, I thought beer chants were something from the Man Show.

oWBmbLi-2iRQm6TRFxYiow.text: I found the beer to be the best thing on the menu.  I had the Liver with Bacon and Onions.  It was goodn if uninspired. I found their version of German Potato Salad lacking.  It seemed that it was 'made to order' and that can be quite pleasing.  In this case,  I found the potatoes sliced oddly in thin strips and completely underdressed. The dressing had little vinegar and no hint of bacon.  My dining partner's Braised Pork Shank was very tender and properly spiced.  I was told that this was superior to Max's Allegheny and found it to be so only in decor an beer selection.

nnPHIu4gOnSIcxwK4YOt0Q.text: I'd rather go here than Hofbrauhaus in winter (I find Hofbrau tolerable only during the summer, where I can sit outside far away from the accordian). The beer is, first of all, fantastic. Secondly, the food is good. It's not great, but it's good. I had the pierogies and those were definitely the highlight. Fresh & covered with buffalo cheese - perfect snack food. I also had fries - also good. The sole disappointment was the Jaegerschnitzel. I thought mine was somewhat uninspiring - not at all up to par with the Hofbrauhaus - although this might be due to the fact that I used to live in Munich and have high standards. My friend had the same thing and loved his. All, in all, I'll definitely be back!

E8Ibsdk5G2vYpQmdNeupow.text: Very good food but small portions. (We only got three pierogis for an appetizer that cost $7!) The beer was amazing, though (St. Nicks)!

MBvWN6Yf21apVwgAeK_h5Q.text: Took a cab from downtown to catch dinner about 30 mins before their publicized kitchen close time. They closed the kitchen early and said they can't help me. Great. Glad I called ahead of time. Now I'm in the middle of nowhere and starving.

ikkL16pyOBgsD7UX2ULaHw.text: Went in for dinner on a Wednesday night. I didn't drink anything because I wasn't in the mood. But, I'd come back and get something to drink and have an appetizer. We started out with the pretzels and beer cheese. It came out with two large pretzels and a container of the dip. It tasted good and may have been the highlight of my meal. For dinner I ordered the Polish hill plate and my boyfriend ordered the Schnitzel. My order came with three pierogis a kielbasa and some sauerkraut.  Overall my meal was just bland. I wasn't sure if the food was made in house, as there wasn't anything that stuck out as being made on the spot. The pierogis didn't have much flavor and the kielbasa was tasty, but had little flavor unless it was dipped in the spicy mustard.  The Schnitzel was fine. Not bad but not really good. The spatzle was fine. Our waitress was nice, seemed a bit overwhelmed but was constantly refilling drinks and running around. Overall the food was mediocre. I think I'd be disappointed if I'd spent 15 dollars on my meal but thankfully I had a groupon. I'll go back but just for drinks and maybe a pretzel or two.

uputAwr9osYTtRsWrjVBAQ.text: Menu could use a little update, and expanded upon. The beer very good and their oktoberfest celebration is something I highly recommend attending (last 2 weekends of sept)

oQHopNfup6yuV22t4hiU9Q.text: Great beer, food and service.  Very cool historical building. Indoor and outdoor seating. Plenty of different German lagers for everyone. Including seasonals.  Had the brezel (Bavarian pretzel with a homemade beer cheese),sourcrout soup, and a huge schnitzel sandwich.  Brian, our server/ bartender, was very friendly and helpful. Recommending beers to go along with our food, and sharing tastes of beers we weren't familiar with. Thank you Brian.  Will return next chance I get!

HGhaDZ1bxfQ3KzlhONTmoA.text: We went for Octoberfest.  I don't know what I was expecting, but it was white tents and aluminum serving trays for brats and wursts.  Sauerkraut was sweet, but good and hubby said it was how his mom made it!  Now I know!  Having it on different levels I guess is a challenge, but really it was people sitting around drinking and talking.  There was a band (wearing their Steelers gear!), but all in all kind of boring.  We were there around 5-ish so I'm sure later in the evening it would get more raucous, but again, with the different levels you kind of lose the "fest" part of it and there wasn't any sort of decorations or banners or anything.  Even the people working were just in jeans and t-shirts.  I looked inside at their menu, which looked good and filling, but the decor of the restaurant wasn't anything that would make me eat inside.  The beer was ok, nothing special.  The Penn Gold was meh, the Penn Dark was meh.

LI4PUU4ld3TJBI9xhqrkhA.text: Penn Brewery is solid. Love the beer cheese, great selection of brews, and always a spacious table to sit and enjoy some kielbasa and pierogis. If I have friends visit the burgh, it's a top 5 spot to take a them to show off our great city.,

mfkgOflrWp0Z_4HP9xcdFg.text: The food was cold and bland. There were four of us in the party, and no one's food arrived even remotely lukewarm. No one was impressed with the entrees we selected. Our server was quite busy (I think the restaurant was short staffed that particular evening). She did her best but often times we waited long periods for drink refills, our appetizers were forgotten to be rung in, there wasn't any silverware on the table so we had to flag down the hostess just to get something to eat with, and it took awhile to have our credit card processed and returned. We waited over a hour to get our food. The restaurant didn't seem that busy but obviously the kitchen was backed up. I understand things like this happen and we weren't in that much of a hurry but the food wasn't worth the wait. We ordered dessert because according to others, they have great desserts - well, the apple turnover was dry and the cookies were stale. No one was impressed. Might go back just to try the different beer selection, but will definitely eat elsewhere prior.

8r4Ep3FiWyzOw9wWTeuGpg.text: Penn Brewery was my destination after a long day's work in Pittsburgh.  I arrived around 9pm on a Tuesday and grabbed a seat without a problem.  I sat at a table right near the glass separating the eating area and the fermenting tanks.  Very cool view there.  I forgot what I ordered, specifically, although I do know it was some sort of sandwich.  The fries here were awesome and so was the Penn-Weizen!  I had a 22oz glass and almost ordered another, but sadly declined because I had to leave quickly after eating.  The view of the brewery is pretty sick once you arrive.  It almost looks sketchy at night, but that's just because it has an old warehouse look to it and I walked down the alleyway to enter the brewery.

cEgOesB8oUQVXgsRgBX1OQ.text: Recently took our family and son's college friends- there were 12 of us- to Penn Brewery on a Saturday night. Had originally planned on going to Hofbrau Haus, but the wait was over an hour long. So we decided to try Penn Brewery. We were immediately seated, which was great. The food was pretty good. The beer also good, but even my 21 year old son commented on the plastic cups they served the beer in. At Hofbrau Haus you are served beer in authentic Hofbrau Haus glasses. I felt like I was at a frat party drinking out of plastic- c'mon, really? And the music! Yuck! It was a hack singer/guitar player singing cover songs. We wanted a german experience, and ended up feeling like we had just been at a college town bar somewhere in the middle of nowhere. The horrible music was so loud we couldn't even hear ourselves talk, which was the main reason we wanted to go out to dinner. We complained twice to management about the loud music, and apparently they don't care what paying customers think. We rushed through dinner because our eardrums were starting to ring. I literally had buzzing in my ears for the next 24 hours from the excessive volume of the music. The whole vibe of the place felt like a dirty frat house- the lower dining level and bathrooms were really dumpy and in need of a makeover. even my son's friends commented on how dumpy it was- so you know it's bad. Overall, the food and beer were good, but don't go there expecting to actually be able to carry on a conversation or hear authentic german music. Spent $270 here and regretted that  we hadn't waited for a table at Hofbrau Haus. I emailed the manager about our experience, and never heard back- I guess they don't care what their customers think. Oh well. We won't go back.

IRzQfBFp3HJAPKB_FnJB4g.text: If it is not Octoberfest, there is no reason to go. This place is completely overrated. The food is not good. I had pot roast and it was so sickly sweet. The schnitzel was overcooked to the point of mushy. It's not like the restaurant is supposed to be high end, but I expect more for $15 entrees esp. in Pittsburgh.  Sure you can go for the beer, but Penn Brewery beer is widely available in  many bars. It's not like the Octoberfest food is that good either.. You go more for the party.

RYX21Mm5Rix2heGAZUWzaQ.text: I have eaten and drank at the penn brewery twice.  The service is subpar.  On our most recent visit, our waiter took our drink and food orders and then simply never returned until the food was served- quite a long time later. Considering that this is a brewery it would have been nice to be able to order a second round of drinks.  We love craft beer and were looking forward to trying several of the offerings.  Better service would have increased our enjoyment of this brewery.  The food was much better than the beer.  I had the filet served over noodles and my husband the sausage platter with German potato salad.  I thought mine was very good and he absolutely loved his.  The prices for the meals were reasonable.  We did not think the beer to be anything special. It was fine but there are many breweries in and around pittsburgh that brew a higher quality beer.

6Wv_zDUsj5YLCXldFU4F8A.text: My husband I and have been twice. The food is great, prices reasonable especially given the generous portions, and the service prompt if uninspired. Small high-topped tables at the bar, otherwise all tables are long German Hofbrauhaus style. There's seating upstairs and in the basement, which doesn't feel basement-y but can be a bit lonely. Once the live music starts, watch out. It's KILLER loud. Located in a bit of a black hole on the near Northside, but plenty of parking and doesn't feel unsafe. Recommended.

XpvEQzTqLO9O9qendSVZaA.text: Drove into town just becaus of the Yelp! reviews we read while passing thru Pennsylvania.  It was about an hour an a half out of our way, but I'd say it was worth it. My wife and I had the fish n'chips while the kids tried the pub burgers. We all thought the food was above average.   The portion sizes were large and tasty, and we all left feeling quite satisfied. The atmosphere was nice, considering the outside of the buidling - they've got a clean open restaurant that we really felt comfortable in.   The staff was all pretty hospitable, too. The only complaint is that when I asked about drinks, the waiter had to explain that every beer on the bottom half of the menu was out.    I understand a craft brewery having times when a particular brew will sell out or be replaced by a seasonal, but HALF THE MENU?   Let's be honest - I'm here for the beer.  I don't care a bit about your food, folks.   Even still, I found beer to drink, and it was a tasty Pils.  The lack of selection is all that kept these folks from getting my 5 star review.

mjwZojS2Bvte8eAqkJUmkw.text: One of the freindliest breweries I have ever been to! Great bartender that really made sure we were welcome and had--his name was Leland. Beer was fabulous...

zlP4M_8CZUo7nI1AVtPxuA.text: The menu is cool. I got the Chicken pirogues that were stuffer with a chicken and buffalo mixture and topped with a blue cheese sauce. It looked like a mess but tasted good. I also had what I thought to be one of the most different items on a menu in a long time Kielbasa Rueben.  The sandwich was just okay. I would have like to taste more of the kielbasa the bread was very over powering. There was also a potato pancake in the middle but couldn't really taste it much. Place was nice inside and I would go back and recommend it to a friend.

d-kHdArmxSxiNX_LCC-dTw.text: Before writing this review, I have to admit, I only went once and I didn't order a full meal.  However, I did drink a lot of beer and I watched my friends eat and it looked fantastic!  So, the thing I can talk about: the beer. DEE-lish! But, really, were we expecting anything less? I hear this place has a great Oktoberfest celebration (at the end of September mind you) and I'm going to have to make a special trip back for that. The Weisen is pretty fantastic, I totally recommend that.  Then there was the food. The happy hour special was half off apps, so that's what I got. Unfortunately I was not a fan. I'm not sure if it's because I didn't really want an app (I wanted food food) but I got it anyway cause it was on special (I'm always looking for a deal - in fact, I might have to change my nickname here to that!). So I got the chicken tenders and pretzels with beer cheese and honey mustard. None of it was really appetizing. Mainly, I can't eat the pretzels but I had a small bite and it tasted pretty awesome. If I could eat bread, I'd probably just have gotten that.  I should have gotten the pierogies. My friend got the dessert - pumpkin pierogies (seasonal only) - and I had a taste...omfg. DEE-lish! Topped with whipped cream and toasted nuts. If you're around and they have it, save room. oh. I think I just drooled on myself a little...  I took a quick trip to the restrooms (I mean, I was drinking a lot!) and I saw other tables' food orders and it all looked good. I will definitely be going back again (not just because there's a cute boy that lives within walking distance!) but because I HAVE to go try their food.

lXI10pMZlUEjiOuYe7sPvg.text: Oktoberfest is here and this is a great time to try out Penn Brewery.  I have only been once since the Brewery reopened under new ownership and so glad they did. Their beers are delicious and highly recommend the Oktoberfest-a great fall beer.  Their Pumpkin Roll Ale is going to be released starting in mid October and I am looking forward to trying this new brew.  It rained the entire night for Oktoberfest but with the tents in the parking lot we were lucky to stay dry. We ate outside instead of insideso we did not order off the regular menu. The outdoor food choices were limited but what they did serve was tasty and perfect with the Oktoberfest. I highly recommend the German potato salad-one of my favorites since it isn't mayonnaise based. I also tried the pulled pork sandwich and bratwurst which was equally as good.  If you do decide to go to Oktoberfest (usually held the last two weeks in September) go early to get a table and beat the crowds.  Parking is very limited so this will ensure a good spot.

iHsvO_PVe7hKg5zG2GJbNw.text: After trying their Oktoberfest (and thoroughly enjoying it) at other Pittsburgh locations, my family and I decided to come and check out the Penn Brewery for an afternoon feast and some brews. Shockingly, they were completely out of their Oktoberfest and it was only early October. (And yes I am completely aware that Oktoberfest traditionally takes place in September not October, but totally not my point). The fact is, if you're an established brewery you should know how much to brew of your seasonals as to satisfy the masses well into the fall months.  We ended up doing a flight of 9 of their other beers. I particularly enjoyed the Penn Pilsner and Penn Dark but was not very impressed by many of their others. However, I'm not a huge fan of hops and high gravity beers and their were quite a few of these on the flight. However, in my mind since I've tried both their Oktoberfest and their seasonal St. Nikolaus Bock (also phenomenal) their beer is still pretty stellar in my opinion.  We ended up getting a bunch of different things and sharing them for lunch. We had the traditional pierogi platter, the potato pancakes, the goulash soup, a side of spatzle, several sides of German potato salad, and the schnitzel sandwich. I was particularly impressed with the German potato salad, which was served warm and was absolutely delicious. The schnitzel sandwich was also excellent. It was a breaded pork cutlet, served with grilled peppers, onions, and mushrooms, and topped with a vinegar slaw, Swiss cheese, and Dijon mustard.   Sadly, the day was rainy and we weren't able to enjoy the outdoor courtyard. However, sitting on the large wooden benches with a view of the brewing system through a large glass window was wonderful.  I would certainly recommend checking this place out!

dmhyHPDwso88bZgRyIPnyg.text: One of the worst experiences I have ever had at a brewery or winery. Sat down at a table for 3 in the bar area. 3pm on 12/26. Half-empty. After 7 minutes and not being helped, despite 3 servers + a bartender, I walked to the bar and asked the bartender if we could order from him or if someone was coming to the table. He said someone would be there in a minute. 5 minutes later, timed btw, not one person came up to us, yet checked on various tables to see if people who already had placed orders or had food were ok. The bartender knew we were waiting, saw multiple servers come up to the bar, and said nothing. Sorry, but 12 minutes to wait for sometime to come by a table for a couple of beers is absolutely ridiculous. As we walked out, we passed one of the servers who didn't even acknowledge us, even though she had seen us waiting there. This place should be ashamed of its unbelievably poor customer service. Truly appalling. Have a great beer somewhere at the strip and skip this brewery.

LR6jYc99XAX3e98kZQZFNA.text: I had a Groupon for Penn Brewery, and was excited to check it out. I forget the type of beer I ordered, but it tasted like Miller Lite. My boyfriend's beer wasn't great either, so that was disappointing. We ordered a stuffed pepper appetizer, which was really good. The peppers were spicy and it was smothered in flavorful tomato sauce and a lot of cheese. I ordered the schnitzel sandwich. It came topped with a dressing, slaw mixture, and pickles, yet it lacked flavor. The schnitzel itself needed salt or some other seasoning! The German potato salad was pretty good--I've had better and worse. I would go again with friends for a good time, but not for the food or beer.

Ef8iqzOldv7qD_-GfdBLHg.text: Love this place.  The atmosphere is great and so are the beers (highly recommend the 10 beer sampler so you can find out what you like).  The German food is also top notch.  Being of the Schnitzel loving persuasion, I was in heaven.  The piece was as big (or bigger) than my face.  The Kartoffelsalat and Spaetzle were really well done.  Had to sit at a small bar table, as the place was packed, so maybe get there early?  Not really an issue otherwise.

Fkdd0DQtuUbxczRecuFPFg.text: I had a German meal and it was very good.  The beer choices were limited to 5 draft brews and some bottled beer.  The beer was okay not outstanding.  They need to create small experimental beers to bring some excitement to an otherwise un-interesting beer selection.  No Oktoberfest or pumpkin beers.  The service was unequal.  Prompt attention upon arrival on a slow Thursday night.  The waiter disappeared when I wanted to pay.  He mumbled something about having to run some cases.  Other waiters ignored me even though I was standing right by the bar and register. I will not return to this place, there are too many other better restaurants in the area.

wsTlaOSQJic7US-02WddiA.text: Wanted to love this place. Loved the cute little courtyard, the building itself, the big wooden tables and benches.  And then I ate and drank here, and was extremely disappointed.  We were there on a Saturday afternoon, and it wasn't particularly crowded. There was no wait for a table, so we got seated right away and ordered a sampler of all the beers they had on tap that day. I think there were six of them that we sampled. Honestly, most of the beers were not particularly memorable, except for the Nut Roll Ale. This beer was pretty much the reason I wanted to try Penn Brewery, and it didn't disappoint. It was a nice, flavorful, aromatic brown ale, and it did indeed smell like your grandma's nut rolls. Perfect.  Unfortunately, nothing else was even close to perfect. The buffalo chicken pierogi ($6.95) were pretty good, but I prefer the traditional potato and cheese laden pierogi. We also ordered the beer cheese and crackers as an appetizer, but were brought a soup by accident. Our waitress was kind of a hot mess, and even after realizing the mistake, it took a good long while before it was corrected, and an even longer while before she eventually brought the check. Iffy service is not something that usually bothers me. I figure, restaurants/bars are busy, the waitstaff have a lot of crap going on, and it's gotta be a long day on your feet. But the service at Penn Brewery was SO beyond iffy that it's hard to even describe. Several times we were convinced that the waitress had forgotten we were there. For example, she would promise to bring out utensils which had been previously forgotten, and then she would disappear for 15 minutes, leaving our food to get cold while we waited semi-patiently for a fork.  Bottom line: The beer was good, the food average, at best, but the service was just awful. Hopefully this was an anomaly.

nkdFQpHc9fEvsEZMAmI-aQ.text: Went mainly for the colaboration beer for Pitt Beer Week. Sat at the bar and sampled mostly everything. Posted our beer reviews on Untappd. They were all good. Didn't have any food. Love older breweries that keep their history.

wy3_ZvuylUE8Bz1-ADoEMA.text: I forget what kind of beer I had, but it was potent and really good. I loved Darren's pierogis and chili. The beer cheese is addictive. My entree, the Rouladen, was a tender, moist winner of a meal and was served in a generous portion. Stupid me had the other half boxed up and then forgot it! Our server was really, sweet, fun, and talked our ears off.

1fAtNK734gn3KECyJuOtRw.text: My German boyfriend was craving German food and hates Hofbrahaus, so we went to Penn Brewery. He... did not get the German food that he wanted. We started off with the Potato Pancakes and they were okay, but some of the potato slivers seemed a little undercooked and they definitely needed some seasoning. I liked my meal - the Kasespaetzle, but it was not authentic. It was just little noodle dumplings in a creamy macaroni and cheese sauce. It was delicious, but I wouldn't call it German food and my boyfriend didn't like it. He had the Schweinebraten, which was okay. He found the sauerkraut to be unappetizing and I don't remember what beer we ordered, but it tasted like the bottom of the keg. It tasted nearly skunked. Gross. We will probably come back and hopefully get beer that isn't on its last legs. It's cool that you can see the brewery through the windows.

LgxewoUywcro9E8CjZPptg.text: Man, we had such a fantastic time here last night!  The Boilermaker Jazz Band was playing, filling the hall with cool 1940's style swing and jazz.  I was actually glad to wait for a table, so the hubby and I could enjoy the show.  The beers were good, and I especially recommend the Marzen and Bock.  Seating is family style, so you'll likely be seated next to strangers if the place is busy.  We like meeting new people, so talking it up with our table-mates and listening to the band made it feel like a party.  A party with 5 different types of wusrt, that is!  I highly recommend starting with the KASE kugel mit speck, which is basically German mac and cheese. Topped with bacon.  Oh yeah.  I'm looking forward to their Mardi Gras celebration!

gApLSPfeinbE2HzjjQCkEw.text: Food was good, but really not German.  Had Beef Stroganoff... it was more like beef noodles with good steak on top. No signs of what should be in Stroganoff,  lol. Oh and you can tell that the mushrooms are added after "gravy" is made. Atmosphere is nice  and the house dark beer is excellent! Would I go back,  probably. .. is it a top 10, no.

357X1c8JjH-a2WzBTX9xDQ.text: Fantastic.  Very authentic food and beer well prepared with great service and first rate entertainment.  1,000 times better than Hofbrauhaus

-5w8i-__jdCExx8a3na_AA.text: Good atmosphere and architecture. Weisen beer was good although bottled. Had every appetizer last night for a work party and every one was bad. Beer cheese pretzel had a side of cheese if I didn't know better was cheez wiz.t

_406n9Q3qoisXsEX8kDRZQ.text: Nice atmosphere and good beer! I got the Arsenal Cider! It was a little on the sweeter side with hints of cinnamon. I love how you can see the beer production area through the window by the bar.

Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

6EIg_oRZ4tmxwswapGbdKA.text: Stop 2 on our Pittsburgh Bike Tour: We had a great bike ride from the strip up to Penn Brewery on the north side. The view from the venue is GREAT! I got awesome pictures of the old Hienz factory and steam stacks from the stoop. The outside of the brew house also set my expectations high; the historic site is complimented by a cute patio/bar area with twinkle lights and cafe-style umbrella tables. Unfortunately, our inside experience was less then impressive. Despite the small crowd, the bartender was inattentive and distracted. We had to request water three times and place our flight order twice. Out of our six pours, my favorites were Tangerine Swirl, Cheater Juice and the Penn Weizen.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

jdegDcNxn86_SF_ywxCykA.text: This microbrewery had an amazing concept. The building used to be the former Eberhardt and Ober Brewery (founded in 1848). You walk in and you can see so much history. We walked in by mistake to the alley and it looked like a Spanish bodega. The ambiance was so relaxed. Food is amazing....German inspired comfort food and German style beers. We had two beers. Of the two, one that stood out was the Penn Weizen. It's a wheat beer with yeast that produces a unique flavor of banana and cloves with a dry and tart edge, some spiciness, and notes of apples....a little hoppy bitterness, and a moderate level of alcohol. It was amazing. The Penn IPA was right there with hop-forward flavor notes. Overall, I would come back here whenever I'm in Pittsburgh.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

Qn8x_nyrFWgs0cHPENIkZQ.text: The best time to go to Penn Brewery is on a weeknight, so you can get seated right away and comfortably. We got a table in the main dining room and luckily not at one of the picnic style tables.   To drink - I ordered the Penn Weizen - it was delicious and I might have ordered a second .  My dad got the Penn IPA, but didn't enjoy it - so he got the Penn Gold instead.   For an appetizer- we ordered the pretzels (they come by 4 an order) so perfect for sharing. However, the last pretzel was under cooked. We reported it to our waitress (and fortunately the manager was able to take of the pretzels on our bill).   For dinner - I ordered the pretzel crusted cod sandwich with a side of fries. The sandwich was on a Breadworks roll. I enjoyed it very much and may have eaten it all. I would definitely get it again.   Heads up - trivia starts at 8pm on Monday's, but they play in the downstairs beer hall.

a3IR4lkNgBCbpSVvk51qTw.text: Never again .. the service was awful the where absolutely not busy but the people working at the moment where more busy with there phones then serving customers. When we where finally able to order it was about 15 minutes before the drinks arrived and another 30 minutes for the burgers where there .. the never asked if we wanted another drink overall experience not good at all. It's a shame because the place is cool

Y-fQyaucRRczIvVr0SQSUA.text: Penn Brewery has been a staple in Pittsburgh for a long time (1986 to be exact). While lots of other breweries have been popping up in Pittsburgh Penn has always stood its ground and continued to keep its character. Penn is in the Deutschtown district of Pittsburgh (North Side) and started its journey doing what I feel they still do the best and thats brewing authentic German style beers. In the past few years Penn has expanded their brewing abilities to add IPA's and seasonal beers to their list.    The atmosphere at Penn Brewery is great. They are located in an old nineteenth century brick building with an awesome biergarten located within it's walls. They offer both upstairs and downstairs seating with views of the brewing process.   Penn also offers one of the best Pittsburgh style restaurants in the city. The restaurant offers many authentic German old world dishes like schnitzel, Wurst, strudel etc. They also offer an extensive menu of Burgers, Sandwiches, Salads (with fries of course), and vegetarian offerings.     Overall Penn Brewery is a major part of the city of Pittsburgh and has what you are looking for in a great brewery. As far as i'm concerned Penn Brewery keeps the old Pittsburgh feel we all love alive and well while continuing to serve great beers and food. A must stop while exploring the city or hanging out with friends and family.

oaVKzyCESGA1jb9HdeD6vw.text: This is an excellent place for German style beers and food. I stopped by here on a Sunday afternoon. It wasn't very busy. The interior is in the style of a German beer hall with long tables with benches and also seating at the bar.   They have some year round beer selections which are similar to the choices you would have at a German beer hall. There's a light beer, a dark beer and a Hefeweizen. I got the dark beer. It was excellent and tasted quite similar to the beers I have had when visiting Germany. The taste was very clean and refreshing. They also have some seasonal beers and IPAs but it seems better to stick with their specialities.   Their menu was fairly large and I decided to get the German Reuben. It was a little pricey at $14 but was worth it. It had very moist and tasty warm sausage slices and warm red cabbage between pumpernickel bread. The only thing I didn't like so much was the hot potato salad because of the sweet glaze.   The interior has a nice dark ambience with a large screen and smaller screen behind the bar that was playing a soccer game. I also saw a very nice outdoor patio.   I'd definitely recommend a visit here if you're a fan of German beers and food.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. German Reuben with hot potato salad. Sandwich very tasty with sliced sausage and red cabbage on pumpernickel. $14

ntiIc8-ZI3RNaxvzZ2kdEA.text: Had a lovely evening on the patio trying the incredible selection of beers! The staff were so knowledgeable and friendly. We didn't stay for dinner this time, but will definitely be back since the food looked amazing!

y5PQJFYbAZOdb2Z-XQI48w.text: Visited Penn Brewery early 2019, on the 2nd January, about 3 o'clock, so it was somewhat subdued at the time. We got some great service at the bar and enjoyed a few brews.    I personally like the standard rotation but the seasonal and specialty were tasty enough.  The Seasonals seemed to be on the creative side, so I felt they weren't fine-tuned to where they could be...  room to develop.    But the food was sensational.  Missus and I split one of the meat and cheese boards.  Yum. Homemade pickles were some of the best ever. Meat and cheese selection was a huge variety, and our portion of food could have fed a family of four. I'll tell you, it was fantastic by both our opinions.   Overall a great experience with great food and friendly folks behind and around the bar.  Atmosphere is a big plus. All the best,

-8tXZO1Tcbpq232PQd1a0g.text: This was our first time checking out Penn Brewery. We shared a beer flight (6 samples for $10) which was a bargain. The beer was pretty good..their Weisse is really good.  I had had the Schweinbraten and my boyfriend had the Brukurst.  Both were nice servings.  Food was on point..tasted great.  Also had their sauerkraut which was delicious.  We will be back.

FQm7GNkdUZ4wJajmAIMYBg.text: I went here with some friends after work.  I tried their nutroll beer for Christmas and their pretzels and cheese dips. They were good.  I was told Santa Claus would be there but I had to leave before he arrived. A cute German beer garden.

4y-tJBdesI6pqzPqIdFFww.text: I always thought Penn Brewery wasn't as cool as some of the new hipster craft breweries.  I STAND CORRECTED! Mr. Bartender was super nice and let me try sips of many options without the slightest bit of attitude. The oyster-based beer was by far the most surprisingly good, and the chocolate stout was my fav.  And the food, THE FOOD!  I was shocked to even find many yummy Vegan friendly options!  We settled on the house-made soft pretzels and cheese, and were not disappointed.  I'm so sad my snobbery kept me from this delightful gem all these years. I can't wait to walk my pup over and enjoy the outside area this summer!

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chocolate beer, house-made Pretzel Sticks with bier cheese

qDUmoFtzQMAlT4GQ1SV9Sw.text: The food and beer are authentic and always perfect! Amazing service on the patio with Audrey. We'll definitely be back!

xmaEXbVqcAT2sSz6UGwqLA.text: Service was exceptionally slow upon arrival in the early afternoon when I was one of four guests in three parties but the pierogies were tasty.

cA_7p-yKEg4F3CUcbhfvYA.text: My partner and I are big brewery fans, but had never been to Penn Brewery.  I give it props for being one of the more "OG" breweries before being a craft beer was hip.  Unfortunately, some of the newer breweries are better and more unique.   I found the beers to be ok.  We sampled a few and I settled on the tangerine swirl.  The taste was light and very drinkable, but I could barely taste the tangerine.  My parter got the ginger beer, which was pretty good.  Not too spicy and didn't have that sting that some ginger beers give off.  We got the pretzels to try and they were DELISH.  I wish I had more things to dip in the cheese spread thing (forget what it was called but it had cream cheese and a hint of spice and was )   I would come back with friends, it's just not at the top of my list of breweries.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. these pretzels and that cream cheesey spread were DELISH!!!

DNM3DKD7jtSx92uPyVm6FQ.text: I love this brewery! So many menu choices to choose from we couldn't decide! The steak salad was delicious. The pierogis were different but my mom enjoyed them. Tons of beer choices as well. Can't wait to come back to try all of the other food and beer choices.

FK8oarzkmIp7-NZiyF8MQA.text: I love this restaurant they have really good food and nice people working and they have good drinks for adults and for kids

BS6_yci4GeQiewPzRDYEvg.text: On a Sunday night, this place was pretty empty. That's fine; I was there for the food and beer.   I ordered the beef kielbasa wurst baguette with hot German potato salad. The kielbasa was hot and juicy. The skin had a good texture, but was sometimes a bit tough to bite through. The kraut was a bit bland on its own. Mustard had a good spice. The German potato salad is in a thick glaze that is quite sweet. When I scraped off half the glaze, it was pretty good.   The Penn IPA was pretty mild, not too hoppy or bitter like I expect. The Cheater Juice was more what I was looking for.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beef kielbasa wurst baguette with hot German potato salad

4My9hIfIwslWjJOhRVgeZw.text: We were visiting from out of town with friends and we looked forward to coming to Penn Brewery for dinner on a Saturday night. The food menu looked great, decent yelp reviews, what could go wrong? We took a $10 Lyft only to find out that they were not taking names for seating but we could stay and wait for a table to open up. Let me explain why that's an awful idea: - People enjoying their evening at a table are constantly being stared at, making them uncomfortable  - People waiting for a table are forced to hover over other patrons - There was a crowd of about 15-20 people all waiting for tables, consolidated near the bar the blocking the waitresses path to the kitchen - There's no guarantee you'll get a table or how quickly - No organization to the chaos  I understand the thought process, it's a lot on a hostess on a busy night to manage a crowd like that. But with the alternative making all patrons feel uncomfortable, that's a quick way to lose business.

H1m7yCSnE839_VS8d_57fA.text: Yummy Sunday evening choice!! My friend and I were looking for somewhere to go..and we were getting hangry! We came in, we're seated promptly, and ordered. They didn't have the pumpkin roll ale I wanted but the server assured me I'd like the nut roll which I did. Out pretzel app was great.. 4 soft pretzel sticks w 3 dipping choices. Lots of salt but just tapped some of it off. Then I had the Rachel which is a lighter version of a Rueben... it was done perfectly on breadworks marble. I had the warm German potato salad.. yummy with a spicy bacon sauce.  We also got a side of spaetzle which was perfect. We will definitely come back here.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Delicious &#34;Rachel&#34;

PBvLPppp4RBv8uZC63XCuQ.text: WOW. What happened to this place?!?! It WAS one of my favorites.  Apparently a change in chef is partly to blame. He apparently has a thing for muenster cheese. This in turn has also produced a change in the menu - neither for the better.  My old standby was the Kielbasa Rueben, which is now the "German" Rueben. Which apparently means it can't have a potato pancake, sauerkraut, swiss cheese, or Russian dressing. It now comes with braised red cabbage, muenster cheese, and hot bacon dressing....a step down after sampling. The "Northsliders" from the app. menu are now also gone.   One 'positive' about the menu is that it seems everything on it is now available all day as opposed to having separate lunch and dinner menus.   Visiting on a GORGEOUS Saturday afternoon, like any normal person I wanted to dine al fresco. Nope, patio not open until 4. Whaaa? Ok whatever.   Tried the sausage platter and intended to try the Deutschtown burger.   Unfortunately since I only said 'burger' when I ordered I just got the basic or classic burger. Who orders one of those anyway unless it's on a kid's menu? I'll take the hit for that I guess, I should have been more clear. But apparently ordering it with no bun also means you don't get pickles or mustard. It was fine, but it sure isn't worth $10.   Same story with the sausage platter. $15 for 3 pieces of sausage? Where the only skill involved in preparing it is turning on the burner. And what kind of kielbasa is that? Not anything I grew up eating.   Disappointed in the changes....but at least the beer is still good!

lYHB7SwNIr3IOX2jJ5oXwQ.text: Got steak delicious steak on thick, creamy Mac and cheese. Everyone at the table wanted my dish. Very good food and amazing table service, highly recommended. It was a good find!!

Rwaplzj7bDGDBGlgGk7OWg.text: Excellent schweinhock for the entre served over mashed potatoes with grilled asparagus. We will each have a second meal to take home.Tried the Penn Gold on tap. Also great if you don't care for hoppy beer. They had something to suit all tastes. For dessert I shared the fried raspberry cheesecake with my husband. Outstanding!

qMXUu39WNymOLkKuJ8bDzQ.text: Oktoberfest! Got pumpkin roll and a Belgium Wheat. Great service and friendly environment!

5ZnzYsvSG93tuITkAiEC1g.text: The night before we went here I had a Penn Dark at a bar.  It was very good, but I rarely drink dark beer.  That being said I was very excited to go to the brewery and have some good German food and beer.  We were seated very quickly and the waitress was nice, but said a guy who was busy would be our waiter....seems that didn't happen as she came right back to take our order.  We order a brezel (Pretzel with beer cheese), and I got a schnitzel sandwich and a Penn lager.  The food came before the appetizer.....guess she was busy too.  The brezel and schnitzel sandwich were fantastic.  The food here is top notch and in my opinion saves this place.  My lager however was awful.  So bitter, I barely got through it.  I decided to get the Octoberfest beer a shot as I tried my girlfriends Penn Gold and thought OK, not great.  The Octoberfest was better, but still awfully bitter and just not very tasty.  I'd go back for the food, but Hofbrau definitely has them on the beer.

_9hvJ8uVGO612TDx4LjxIA.text: While my family was in town for Christmas, we decide to go to Penn brew on a Wednesday night for dinner. Of the 6 of us who ordered, 4 of us could not get what we wanted because the restaurant had run out. We were informed that they were out of all pierogies(in all varieties), all spaetzle, and vegetarian sausage. We were only informed that the potato and cheese pierogies were out after two people order them.   The wait staff, although trying to be accommodating , seemed a bit over their head and there seemed to be a complete disconnect between the front and back of the house.  When the orders finally arrived, one of the orders was wrong, making 5 out of 6 orders not what people wanted. Keep in mind that this was at 7:30pm, not late night when I would expect a restaurant to run out of food.  The food that did arrive was pretty mediocre. The steak sandwiches were tough and dry. The fries were good. The salads had too much red onion. The potato soup was bland except for being too salty. The appetizers we had were pretty good but the grilled veg that cam with the hummus was cold.  The only thing positive of this visit was that the beer was good.

Q_dPpVRdu224HBPU-5ZCZw.text: We came in after spending the day at the Science Center.  Love the courtyard dining area, but we wanted air conditioning and to check out the inside.  We got a monster table all to ourselves.  Nice.  Even nicer was the view of downtown.  BJ got a Penn Wheatson beer.  It was very good, simliar to a Blue Moon or a Hoeggarten.  Since we were feeling a little German, BJ got the pierogi plate and I got kasespatzle.  We liked both our dishes.  My accompanying salad had some brown pieces of lettuce. But I forgave that because our server was kind enough to bring us a sample of the hot German potato salad.  All in all, a pretty decent meal.  But of course, we always going to like any brewery.

DLP9b0-i0Jeeg-FhVjoicA.text: This is, easily, one of the best brewpubs in the country. You can probably find better beer elsewhere, and you can certainly find more selection and more interesting beers elsewhere (even in Pittsburgh), but the collection of good food, great beer, great atmosphere and a really venerable history. Sit out on the patio, drink a pilsner and eat some sausage. I don't know that there's a better way to spend an evening in Pittsburgh.

d9zcXOBsoCR0lumIbWmj5w.text: I experienced the Penn Brewery for my first time, and I had a good time with my friends and drank some good beer, but the food just wasn't up to snuff.  First things first, the beer.  I had a couple St. Nikolaus Bock Bier's and I thoroughly enjoyed them.  It was dark, malty, and tasty.  For dinner I had the wienerschnitzel w/ spaetzle.  The wienerschnitzel was dry and had a metallic taste to it, and the spaetzle, depending on the bite, was okay or just burnt tasting.  I will definitely go back to drink, and maybe much on a couple things, but never again for dinner.

aNzbCYYDh5HpD7d4jTawFA.text: Recently the revamped their menu and added some new choices! The chicken gyro and potato pancakes were soo good!

cMwRjwRNJw0i4hoVii_0eg.text: Came up here on Wednesday for a little supervisory luncheon (and note to the taxpayers, we did pay for it ourselves).  Penn Brewery is probably one of the oldest microbreweries/brew pubs around.  I can't vouch for their beers since I'm a non-drinker but their lunches here are really good.  Penn Brewery is meant to emulate a German bierstube and the atmosphere here is just so gosh darn fun, it almost doesn't matter if the food is any good.  Well not quite.  Who wants to eat lousy food?   I can't remember what the others ate, but we did start off with an order of  Penn Brewery beer cheese, flavored with their house brew.  I believe one of my coworkers had the scnitzel sandwich but I went for the sausage baguette--a grilled bratwurst with sauerkraut.  Mmmmm, I love stinky food!  Kiss me Rick, darling!

59VFVNCx_-OmIUNtmjc_vQ.text: Having been to Penn Brewery a few times lately and them having a groupon available, I invited 2 couples out for dinner.    Firstly, they sat us directly next to a band making it impossible to hear each other and the waitress.   Second, although the food was mostly as good as before, the portions were much smaller than what we've had in the past with the same prices.  This was a big let down.  Lastly, we had 3 couples, 3 separate checks and they would only let us use 1 groupon for the entire table.  I understand this is in the fine print but this is the only reason we came even came here to eat.  Never experienced this problem before with groupons.  Now we have to come back to use them, I'm sure that will be the last time.

2eaE7l8TG7VDL4mHVTLfoQ.text: Beer was good but food was mediocre at best. I will not be going there ever again because I did not feel welcome. Not impressed with service.

ZLgr6KHWNXqB-1iYbwt8ng.text: Great German food options....so it's not Hofbrauhaus or Church Breworks.  It's a Pittsburgh institution and the beer is great, awesome selection of pierogis and German food.    Additionally live music options, even during the week are fantastic!

fefCw2xJdO_lBVr6LJA0zQ.text: By far one of the worst experiences I've ever had. the place we sat at didn't have a light so we were in darkness, asked the waitress to see if she if she can change it she basically told me to politely fuck off. Didn't have half the beer on the list. Waited two hours to receive food. Waitress came to our table every 30 minutes! Waited another 30 mins to get out beer.  My friend got cold pirogies.... I have been waiting for my check now for 30 minutes as well. Never ever again. I will never return to penn brewery and I recommends that no one ever goes here. If it wasn't for for my friends I would've thought I was in hell.

TwsakK05wBP9s-4KGs4VBQ.text: Do yourself a favor and enjoy a good meal BEFORE you arrive. The restaurant is lovely. Great lighting - loads of warm wood. The staff s super friendly and nice. The beers are fantastic. but the food? pretty awful.   My husband opted for the steak frites - the fries were excellent but the steak? greasy and about as flavorful and tender as chewing on an old leather shoe. I ordered the Sauerbraten with kraut and german potato salad. what arrived was two slabs of hard, grey meat that lacked any flavor (hello? season your food, please) and was dry and tough. i was so hungry that i forced down half of it but just could not manage to talk myself into choking down the other piece. The potato salad was pretty good but the kraut was awful - no flavor. ugh. the plate was a mess.   at the end of the meal we were comped dessert due to table shuffling and big parties arriving etc... the chocolate raspberry cake was excellent, I suspect brought in and they make a good cup of coffee.   All in all, come for the beer but pack a sandwich. I would be hard pressed to every find myself inside Penn Brewery otherwise.

_ut62eAG4hwDiRqUj_cllQ.text: German style brau haus. They really have seemed to nail it.  They have most of the the authentic styles of German beers.  They were missing Kolsch and Alt bier but I was told that these rotate in...so I will just have to come back.  The menu is absolutely traditional and reads to be the real deal.  Be aware that I did NOT eat a meal here, only read the menu.  One thing missing is sweinhaxe but this is not easily done with fresh ingredients as ankles are not as readily available in US as Germany.  I will definitely come back and give an update when I have had the chance to really eat.  For any beer fan or German food aficionado, I think that you will be pleased to stop here.

TLeC_fpSqqrJ0eK7zurChA.text: The Penn Brewery is a great place for large groups. They accommodated 65 of us with little notice. The food was quite good and the service was excellent. They were organized and the food still came out quickly. The servers deserve 5 stars for their professionalism. The cooks put a lot of care into each plate that came out.  The potato pancakes rock!

PIrMC5EYBeCbFWZ9lHPlSw.text: I really wanted to love this place. Hell. I used to love this place. For the food, anyway. I'm not a beer drinker, but I'm into eating food. The service here, however, leaves something to be desired.  On previous visits to Penn Brewery we've enjoyed dining outside and have enjoyed the food. This week, we were excited there was a Craft Beer Week event here and the collaboration beers had the BF all in a tizzy. We made our way there (in rush hour and everything!), parked in the mini garage and made our way inside. Inside, it was a madhouse. The bar was jam packed. The tables were full. The hostess stand was abandoned. We awkwardly stood at the hostess stand since we were hoping to get some food while we were there. No one came, and no one came. When an employee finally came over, it was like he didn't know what a hostess stand was or how to operate said hostess stand. He was confused about what to do, handed us menus and told us we could sit anywhere. We snagged a table from two women who were about to leave and started to look over the menu. After a few minutes and no sign of a waiter, a waiter came over and asked us if we'd been seated here. Yes, we said, we were given menus and told we could sit here. 'Welllll (I'm channeling all three nasal-y Kardashians here), you can't sit here. There's a long wait.' But- b-b-b-b- the man said we could sit here :( 'Yeah, there's a really long wait.' This woman was SO rude. I was immediately peeved. We'd already been ignored, given False information and THEN rudely told to move like we were some sort of aliens trying to jump the 'wait' list. We were not offered to have our name put on the list while we waited at the bar, we were just told to MOVE IT. I looked at this rude waitress, looked at my accomplice, and said, "CAN WE LEAVE?" And we did. I tweeted them about it and they said 'We are very sorry about that! We'll let the staff know so we can prevent that in the future.' But what's done is done. And no free app or anything? Fuh-GET about this place and its shenans. If I need a raucous night of German beer drinking I'll head to Hofbrauhaus. Hmph!

Pni0DQ7l418wkXxP85b5gw.text: This was a great stop. We were visiting Pittsburgh and I wanted to treat my hubby to a brewery trip. His favorite. We were not disappointed. I was pleasantly surprised to see that the place had German food. Yum! We also had a sampler of their beers. Pretty diverse flavors.  We were there on a Saturday afternoon, so it wasn't super crowded. Had a nice casual vibe though. They have a nice patio on the side that must be great on a warm night. They also had a huge party room down on the  first floor.  All around a great stop. I did see that someone mentioned a downtown view. I was excited to see it, but the only downtown view I saw was from inside the elevator. Downtown view not so much. Hit the inclines instead.

30QlWwnrJKd_HMvmXwrYyA.text: This is an excellent example of what a German American brewery should be! They have a beautiful, quaint outdoor beer garden with an old cobblestone courtyard. So much history there, it's almost like taking a step back in time, if only momentarily.   The staff was very hip and cool, in a friendly way. We were seated promptly in the outside beer garden at a bistro table around 5:30 on a Friday night. The menu was very extensive, some of it even being in German. And my inner Canadian rejoiced at the variety of poutine they offered. So of course I had to try it along with a flight of beers. It didn't disappoint! Neither did the soft pretzels or strudel! And the beers were excellent! I can't wait to go back there when I'm in town! Highly recommend! Family friendly, fun for everyone!

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Poutine sooooo many ways!
Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

a09VQRRF7Eckai6OXnJ8xg.text: Fish & chips were great!  Pretzel crust is crunch, the fries ("chips") are the exact right kind for malt vinegar...my favorite!!  Great service, a bit pricey, but we used a Groupon and it was very affordable.  We were there at 2pm on a Monday.    6/2/2019- Around 2 PM on a Sunday at Penn Brewery. There were four tables occupied. I had the buffalo chicken pierogies, which come with blue cheese crumbles according to the menu, but instead it came with a white sauce that tasted faintly like blue cheese. What a disappointment.  If I'd known they were going to pour a weak blue cheese dressing on the pierogies, I would've said put it on the side. He ordered a bacon cheddar cheeseburger. The bacon was not on the burger. We visited here many times, it must've been an off day. But for the prices and lack of business on this day,  I think things should've gone a little better. We will be back, but next time, I will complain if there's a problem.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Hamburger and french fries.
Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Buffalo chicken pierogies...menu says it comes with blue cheese crumbles--it came with a blue cheese flavored dressing.  :-(

vRK4C4uTkmlQsF78qqgN8g.text: Came here for the first time.  We ordered their pretzel breadsticks appetizer, the Wurst platter, their 5hour brisket, and the salted caramel cookie dessert with vanilla ice cream.  What's hot - Cost.  I purchased a $25 Groupon for $13, which was a money saver.  Our total bill came out to around $25, including tip.  This Groupon looks to be regularly offered, as well.  Their wait staff are familiar with it, which is good.  Always great saving money! - Good menu variety.  There are appetizers, cheese spreads, burgers, pizza, sandwiches, etc...  It's a big menu, but there's something for everyone. - Some of the food is good.  Despite my dish, which I mention below, most of the food was decent.  The pretzel breadsticks appetizer is served with a warm cheese, a mustard dip, and some cheesy type of cream cheese dip.  Their mustard has a slight spicy kick at the end, which is cool.  Don't come across very flavorful mustards in most restaurants, so this was a yummy difference.  The salted caramel pretzel cookie dessert was yummers- warm, soft, gooey, and sweet but not too sweet.  What's not - The wait.  First time we came here, the wait was hella long, so we left.  I made sure to make a reservation for the next time.  Based on what I've seen and experienced, dinner times are busy, so make a reservation.  Their dining area is kinda small and not spread out, so be prepared.   -  Bland food.  My food (the brisket) was bland.  The Vietnamese sausage wasn't flavorful and the German dumplings were bland, too.  The brisket was tender and moist, but no flavor.  Dudes, I asked for hot sauce!  My point- be aware that not everything on their menu is flavorful and yummy.  You should probably ask the wait staff for their feedback if flavor is an issue for you, like it is for me.  The menu also said my dish came with bean sprouts and root vegetables.  No bean sprouts.  What were the root vegetables?  Carrots and celery. - Cost.  Despite my Groupon, not everything is a reasonable price.  For example, they have pierogis that are $9 for 4 pieces.  That's high- $2 per pierogi?  Really? - Noise.  It gets noisy here pretty fast and it doesn't take much for this place to be crowded.  Be prepared that this place isn't the easiest to socialize and talk, unless it's really the booze you care about. - Parking.  Not the easiest.  They do have a parking garage behind the restaurant, but it's not the easiest to find.  Don't even bother looking for street parking.  It's so limited. - Service.  The wait staff seem to be spread thin, which means it's not always easy to flag someone down when you need something.  Their wait staff aren't rude.  They just don't seem to have enough staff, so service can be slow.  Final answer Willing to come back, but not a first choice.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Salted caramel pretzel cookie with ice cream
Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. 5 hour brisket with Vietnamese sausage and German dumplings
Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Wurst platter with hot potato salad

MV3wfilv-MkBltQCKAJesg.text: I've always heard about this place but this was my first visit. We came and had a 2 hour wait for a Saturday night so we signed in and went to other breweries in the area while waiting, they called us at our turn so that was cool.   The bench seating area was cool and the whole atmosphere was a very nice vibe - random mixes of different crowds dancing together to the band. I would say the whole environment and music are the best things about this place.   The beer selection was seriously lacking to me for a popular brewery. Maybe it's just me but I expected more specialty beers, given the hype. The food we got was decent but nothing spectacular. We came for the halfway to Octoberfest menu - pretzel appetizers, wing plates, sausage platters, ruebens - we got a mix of different dishes and shared them all. The service was very prompt and excellent. It's a cool place to checkout, especially for out of town friends, but the drinks and food were nothing special in my opinion.

yT7LegQdbnDqe8Ps5S1Kzw.text: I will start saying I did enjoy my visit. The good: decent beer. Friendly quick service. Food is solid & comes out fast. Cool part of town (my tourist take).  The "eh": Feels like a chain. Beer taste more like mega-brewery than craft. 8 years ago I would have loved this place.... the explosion of great little craft breweries has just kind of passed it by on the brewery scene. That being said, if you enjoy big box restaurants you will probably really enjoy a trip here..... it does have a fun vibe. Drink local!

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

pHmAos1RVW6lPntUaJsB3Q.text: Nice selection of craft beers. Good selection of brewhouse style pub grub. There's also outdoor seating in the summer which makes it nice because there are no things on the wall and no carpet which makes for a very loud main room. If you want to have a conversation make sure you sit outside

vdFuiefeOmN5Fm4isR3h_g.text: A pretty fun spot in the North Side. The restaurant space has a nice atmosphere, maybe a little on the louder side but it's a brewery so I'd say thats appropriate. This place is good for large groups, there were many there last night. Happy hour runs from 4 until 6, they had some decent specials. Their Penn Weizen is my favorite beer they have. Our service tonight was great. The food was very good too, I went with the burger which was great with the beer. My one hesitation here is the prices, things are perhaps a bit overpriced. I also was charged $1 for cheese on the burger despite the menu not saying this -- not anything life-changing but still. I ordered the pierogis to go for someone and they did not really like them and thought for $9 they were not worth it. Overall, a solid place to check out in Pittsburgh, especially for those visiting.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Brew House Burger

8Tq6QPre4MBysLPffVxBIA.text: Recently visited the Pittsburgh International Airport location while waiting for a flight.  This location here opened not too long ago. Having been to the brewery in the North Side many times I found it to be consistent.  The food was good and I think Penn has decent beer. Service was good at the airport which is key when you need to eat and pay relatively quickly at times to catch a flight.  The tables are a bit crammed together but then again it's the airport.  All in all I think it's a good addition and will plan to stop again while waiting for a flight.    I have also always enjoyed the Oktoberfest weekends at the North Side brewery and recommend that, usually occurs in mid to late September each year.  You really can't beat the charm of the building!

Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

RW38lCfpxBnlrWAiSBlKAQ.text: Penn Brewery is a historical place as they are housed in the historic Eberhardt and Ober Brewery building. The abundance of historical value in the building and brewery is incredible from were there brewing is done to the caves that houses the casks of beer.   Food If you are looking for AUTHENTIC german cuisine this is not the place, but the food is good. I've had the jagerschitzel and kaissespatzel and have to say they are not bad at all. They have flavor but the jagersnitzel is a tad dry.   Beer This is where the brewery shines, from their seasonal beers (you have to go to the tapping the cask parties), to their normal weissens and stouts. All around the beers have great taste and aromas. No two are alike either. In the off-season (November to January) they always experiment with new flavors for the next year.  Atmosphere Great family atmosphere, but it does get a tad loud during the night or during Oktoberfest, but the service is good and the people there genuinely seem like they like it there.  Overall, Food is mediocre, but the Beer is awesome.

vks_s41we18cUaz_R6Ue3Q.text: The management and service has gone way downhill.  Too bad. The food and beer are really great.  Won't be back. Three strikes you're out.

b5QGlGnpyseXaP-nT8cbSA.text: My partner, kids, and I decided to finally check out Penn Brewery after living in the neighborhood for nearly a year but seeming to never get ourselves down there until now. It was busy but we got a table right away and were served by Justin, who was really nice and gave us great service.  We started with the Butcher Plate, a charcuterie that offered meats, cheese, pickled items, bread, and a nice swipe of spicy mustard; we got the smaller size board which was still plenty of food for two people. Everything on it was delicious.  We each decided to grab some beers; I went for the Penn Weizen, which is a favorite of mine, and my partner decided to try a Weizenbock. He ended up ordering another, so I imagine he liked it. I took a sip and it wasn't as strong tasting as I was expecting based on the color, which for my taste preferences was a good thing. The Penn Weizen is -delicious-; it's missing that light banana aftertaste that a lot of Hefeweizens have, and I am perfectly ok with that since it's plenty flavorful and aromatic.  For dinner, the kid's menu had plenty to offer our picky eaters. My daughter got a cheeseburger and fruit cup, which she devoured. My son got the cheese pizza which was a pretty generous serving. My partner got the Schweinebraten, and while he did enjoy it, he said he may have preferred something else since it kind of seemed like a pork chop type meal that I have made at home before. I got the sausage platter which I really enjoyed; each sausage had a unique flavor and texture, none too spicy or too bland. The kraut is better at Hofbrauhaus but Penn's was perfectly fine. The warm German potato salad was delicious and almost had a taste of honey to it.  Overall we had a great experience, and being that we live a mere 5 minutes up the hill, we plan to make more trips to Penn Brewery in the future, even if just for some beers and the Butcher Board.

zm5z2otHv6tYTYrsxAVn0w.text: Ok came here on a Friday during rush hour and a Pirates game so we had a bit of traffic around exit 1D. Once we got here I saw a lot of no parking signs and a lot of people ignoring them, so I hopped out of the car to ask the girl at the check-in table at the bier garten entrance where I should park. I expected to hear something like "anywhere - they don't enforce after 5" or directions to a lot. Nope she answered with complete bewilderment "Park?! Wow, I have no idea."  One of the stupidest people or she was playing me for a fool, not sure which.   I was determined to find a place to park, though, instead of just going over to El Burro, because I had this Groupon expiring the next day. So I got back in my car and turned left and BAM there's the parking structure - complete with stair access into the bier garten.  A lot of adjectives spewed forth at this point but I'll keep those to myself.   We opted to eat inside instead of outside (because of the heat, not that ditz at the entrance), and were sat right away at a table near the brewery works.  It was pretty loud in there.  To eat, I ordered the schweinebraten. The best part was the broccoli. I think it was the best prepared broccoli I've ever eaten.  It complimented the rest of the dish perfectly. The good part was the mashed potatoes and gravy. It was very tasty - and necessary. The ok part was the pork itself.  It was too dry and bland tasting.  Without the mashed potatoes and gravy, I wouldn't have been able to eat much of it. Frankly I've had better pork roast at the AVI cafeteria at work.    The chocolate stout was great the first 1/3 but after that I found the chocolate flavor to be too much. The weizen, however, I found to be refreshing and elegant. Much better than the Pittsburgh Hofbrau's!  That was my companion's choice, and I liked it enough that I got a 5oz pour as an after-dinner drink to round out the evening.   The mug the chocolate stout came in added to the experience. It was dimpled and had the look of a barrel.   Like the pork, the waitress was also bland (personality-wise) but no complaints with her core function. We would have had another round of beers if she checked back in time. (Asking if we're good as she walks past us without stopping doesn't count.)  I didn't like that she asked to take my companion's phone to the bar to scan the groupon barcode.  I would have said no to that!  Really I want to give them a 3 but these unusual things tonight didn't get in the way of us having a good time so 4 it is.
