LyPQ4Eeufcvhea5gwDZyDw.text: We went for the first time on a Thursday. It was not very crowded and we had a very attentive waitress. We had appetizers along with dinner and drinks and everything was very good. My husband has one of their 10 beer flights and you get a lot of beer! It was a great pace to catch up with friends. The food came quick and was very tasty I took half of my sandwich home with me! I had their Octoberfest beer which was so good! I would say not a lot of parking but again for a Thursday we like park right outside. Also, keep and eye out for groupons!

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Beer flight

FvFsuBDDwA5eZGHHib-QZw.text: Great outdoor seating, and you can bring your dog! Food was good! The beers were tasty! Overall I enjoyed this brewery! Parking is plentiful!

Ho_s9_JqwZk10vDwZRAJgw.text: Finally went here for a friends birthday and found myself intrigued by the menu.   As a plant based advocate I appreciated that they had so many vegan and vegetarian options while also having many of the Pittsburgh staples that are popular in the region.  As for the quality of the food I found it to be a very "hit or miss" kind of place. While I loved the BBQ jackfruit sandwiches I wasn't as much a fan of the portabella mushroom "vegan cheese steak" sandwhiches. Although I loved the garlic shrimp appetizer I didn't think the fried okra and fried green tomatoes were on that same Caliber.  Since they have such a huge menu I would recommend they cut it in half and only focus on the menu items they are good at executing. Nonetheless, I appreciated the generous portions and the excellent customer service!

0N9vdoR4uexTlGEiX0wF-g.text: We had a few bad food/bad service visits last year. We stopped in 2 weeks ago with friends for a beer while riding bicycles. The beer has always been excellent. Anyway the bar tender, Dj, talked us into stopping back for food next time. Well I'm glad he did. The service AND the food were fantastic. So thank you to everyone at Penn Brewery for the excellent food and service.

L83fq8lwpWwLVmnSMZ4JSQ.text: I don't know why I haven't visited in all these years - but in the matter of a week I ended up at Penn Brewery twice.   High points: Beer samplers are always great - and with the variety of selection at Penn Brewery, there was plenty to pick from and it was great sharing size. We had the poutine, which was delicious - it was huge though! Way too much for an app for 2 people, so we kind of wish we had just stopped there. We also had the mac & cheese (mostly saved it for left overs) because I really wanted to try their dessert menu.   The location is great - there is a parking garage just up the street that holds a decent amount of vehicles and there is a small amount of street parking near by. There are several picnic style tables, making it a good location for a group - as long as you get there at the right time.  The second visit was just for a beer and some pretzels. We were able to get a 4-top table much earlier than they originally told us to sit as a group rather than huddle around the bar. Good beer - good pretzels. I'd recommend checking it out!

Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Samples galore!

sKybZmjX7bgPvq7E77v3og.text: I've visited a few more times since my last trip, and overall my feelings toward Penn Brewery have improved! Most recently, I visited with my sister and my parents and we had a great experience. Everyone loved their food and we loved sampling their delicious brews. What keeps me coming back is their adorable beer garten- can't go wrong enjoying a cold brew back there!

QkEhaBcCmOND1q3_XNbyOg.text: Me and the lady came by here on a Tuesday for "Fat Tuesday" we seen they had a event going on featuring a live band so decided to check it out. It was both of our first time here. Not know what to expect we where a bit surprised on the set up. On walking in it seems like a old school and there doors that open up into a seating area. The staff was friendly from the conversation we had noted it was extremely loud with the band playing and hard to hear. We where advised it would be roughly a twenty minute wait we said that was fine. We got note a table was ready a lot sooner if we where okay with sitting at a longer table with other people. We agreed just being so hungry and wanting to sit down. Once seated our server was nice but it was very busy so things where very fast with talking just to get the order in and move on to someone else. I settled with the po boy for the limited special menu they had for the event and She got a chicken salad. We started with the pretzel appetizer just to have something to snack on in the mean time. The pretzels where good but the dips where much better and made it go well together. The pretzels by there selfs where very boring. As for the po boy it was a major disappointment. There was hardly any shrimp on it and it was missing the house made pickles on the actual sandwich. It was a okay dish but nothing to hype up. On top of that the server said any side was included in the dish so I got the Mac and cheese and that was great. But when the bill came it ended up being a up charge of six dollars if I remember correctly. I don't mind paying for it but to not know the menu to inform guest is a big issue. My date enjoyed her salad but that's pretty hard to mess up. Overall I would return down the road on a less busy night to try the other menu when things are less hectic. This was just a huge let down on something I was really looking forward to because this event and the food could have been so much better.

lifmucbwKMB1wIF3_gvINw.text: Fun fun place! Great views. Love the building it's in. It's a little loud in the restaurant, but once you've had a few beers it's fine. We had wurst on a pretzel bun with mustard and sauerkraut which I thought was excellent. I never had speatzle before so I'm not sure what's authentic. These were drenched in dry bread crumbs which I didn't find all too appealing. It's worth going just for the atmosphere itself. Will definitely come back when in town.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

NrD55qvWgRv9xqQIIlux8g.text: This review is for drinks only. I was so excited to try this place out after growing up in Pittsburgh then moving out of state but I must say - It was just alright. Compared to many of the other breweries popping up in the area, they have very few beers on tap and not a very wide range of beer styles. I had the seasonal (I think an Oktoberfest) and it was OK.  The atmosphere was dark and pretty crowded at the bar, but the restaurant area was more open (though not any brighter).   I would return to try the food because I've heard good things, but I wasn't impressed by their beers (and they're a brewery!)

Y98BX-JnsDJIH5CbyyknIA.text: This was our first stop off the plane. The beer was really good, Penn Dark, and the food was just as amazing, German Ruben. The bartender was amazing and showed up helpful. The manager/GM was also in site and shot the shot with us. I recommend this place to anyone.

bGtLuVPwoMciVE8Ov_hqcA.text: If there is one word that comes to mind in thinking of Penn Brewery, it is "LOUD".  Even being seated far from the boisterous, large party, my companion and I had to raise our voices to be heard as the acoustics are awful with no carpeting. Do not dine here unless you are willing to deal with a lot of noise. The food is excellent.  Her gyro and my jaegerschnitzel with brown gravy were delicious and the portions ample.  The accompanying french fries and mashed potatoes were top-notch. No bread was brought or offered. I did not realize that my beer sampler was a hefty $17, but for ten decent size glasses, the price was fair.  If one person were to consume all of it, they would likely stagger out of the establishment.  Apple strudel with cinnamon ice cream was the perfect ending.  The meal was $61+ for two plus tip.

P1PyusIuecXdfe_rCkh6jg.text: I was so disappointed today! I've come to expect a pretty good German meal when I head to Penn Brewery. Today, however, was not that good meal. The menu has become Americanized. Sauerbraten was described as pot roast and served with potatoes. There was no spatzel to be had. The braised red cabbage was missing something. I was so sad. The pretzels with beer cheese was great. My husband's jaggershinzel was good. But, if you really want good German fare- go to Max's up the road on the North Side. Penn Brewery has just gone down hill.

pa8vx6FoOGeH5fsdDnNY7Q.text: Okay for beer lovers.  Quite loud and the food is mediocre.

r4o55O5zfpAJsEOSx716IA.text: I had a groupon that was expiring, so we decided to try out Penn Brewery.  I have heard mixed reviews from friends.  I wanted to give it a try.  This is what we ordered  The bloomfield flatbread pizza- I'm a fan of goat cheese, so i thought this was really good. The buffalo chicken pierogi- This was delicious.  It seems like you can't go anywhere in Pittsburgh with out seeing a buffalo chicken something these days.  This was a pleasant surprise. veggie burger- not the best veggie burger I've had.  It was sort of dry, with chunks of corn and red pepper (i think it was red pepper).  it's not served with mayo, mustard, hummus spread or anything as a condiment for the burger.  The waitress didn't ask, so I assumed it came with something...but for the price, I shouldn't really complain.  It came with fries, that were super good.  Perfectly salted, skin on fries that were cooked crispy.  Yum! Pretzal w/ beer cheese- carbs and cheese...no complaints here!  I enjoy the Penn Brewery Beers.  I've had the pilsner, gold and dark.  All 3 are easy to drink and tasty.  The service there seems to allow you to enjoy your meal and drinks.  It's feels like a communial, social, gathering place.  The staff isn't bothering you a million times while you eat.  Overall, I liked the place, and would recommend it.  We didn't have any entrees, so I'm not sure how those dishes are but our appetizers and flatbread were worth trying.

trtud6qid7-4x6F36T7W8g.text: 4.5 Stars. It's been years since my first visit to Penn Brewery, so I wanted to refresh my memory while I was back in the area. First, it's not in the most convenient location up on Troy Hill, but still pretty easy to get to from either Route 28 or I-279. Parking is a little on the rough side, in a gravel lot across the street. That's apparently an issue for some, but I could care less...it's free! Can't say that about very many places in the city.  After walking through the courtyard and walking up the stairs, I noticed the lunchtime crowd wasn't too busy. I read through the Penn Brew drafts listed on the chalkboard behind the bar and decided to try the Penn Dark (of course). The I looked at the menu and saw this:  "Bacon Brew Dog: A natural-casing hot dog stuffed with fresh jalapenos, wrapped in bacon, then deep-fried and topped with BBQ sauce, shredded cheddar Jack cheese, and vinegar slaw in a hot dog bun."  SAY WHAT!?  I told the bartender that's what I wanted and he grinned and said "Oh, those are really good. I haven't had one in awhile. Nice choice."  Long story short, it was awesome! I probably could've eaten two of them, albeit I would've paid the price for it dearly later on. The friendly bartender also let me sample some of the other brews, including Penndemonium (Brewer's Choice Series) and Summer Berry Weiss (seasonal), both smooth, refreshing and sweet.  I'm very happy I revisited Pittsburgh largest and oldest brewery, but slightly bummed I missed out on their $3 Happy Hour drafts. Good thing to remember for next time.

Q215hyf0KGXKVUqa_GOLjA.text: This is a very cool craft brewery located in a restored, old industrial building.  The beers were all good and the staff was very friendly.  They serve food too, although we only had beers.

6-dRJjzPgRzoraaRpvrEtw.text: I really wanted to like this place, but going to a brewery and they hand you a menu and tell you they only have 3 beers available?! FAIL! Especially when they are out of their seasonal Oktoberfest beer-and its Oktober...you're a brewery, you know the demand for somehting like this.   Anyway, service was mediocre, we moved to a larger table when some family arrived, I had to ask 4 times to include 2 beer stiens into the bill. The bill arives (finally) no stiens were listed. I asked our waitress AGAIN...it took her forever to come back, I figured she was hand blowing them in the back. I contemplating walking over to the bar and helping myself but I refraiend.   All in all, if I'm ever in town again I most likely wont come here. It was a total let down. *sad face*

klBDnLntmOedOYRF9IAwcA.text: Great beer with seasonal selections and authentic German food (my favorite is the schnitzel) with portions big enough to share.

tnquJdJ6l0cjOhX8dAFaUQ.text: If your website says open until midnight, I should be able to get a beer at 11pm and not have you say "We're closed".  Learn how to run a business.

DYUra6QSsBXwGqQYdxsuQQ.text: Went on a Saturday evening. Was sat in the back corner. Took 15 minutes for a waitress to welcome us and offer drinks. Waited and waited. Took food order. Order arrived wrong which she corrected but took forever to cook. The waitress was horrible but pleasant person. I know it gets busy but felt misplaced because there wasn't any focus. Food was good and customer service is very important. My advise is a hit or miss place. Most likely won't go back.

y9Ek_mF_GZLG7kPCTrEVtQ.text: We were here most recently for the Yelp party, so keep in mind that a place that is giving you free food and beer almost always wins.  It's an excellent business model to get good reviews, but quite awful if you have any interest in making money.  However, I have been here before, and it's really cool in just about every way.  The coolest being was that it was an actual Civil War era brewery apparently, and has a bunch of secret catacombs that they used to store ingredients, and quite possibly, dead bodies.  You can schedule a little mini-tour of the brewery, which is pretty cool as well.  The food is good to very good, and the beer is really awesome.    The only bad thing is parking.  There is an attached garage, so if you make it in there, you're safe.  If you don't there's a terrible unpaved, unmarked lot that takes you across a street that has a blind curve and cars driving a million miles an hour.  I lost many frogs trying to get across that road, and my heart aches for each of my dead friends.  But we did make it across eventually and had a wonderful time.

Q1KqkBhoOdwlC4a3CuD14w.text: They were out of multiple beers ( the wheat and ginger beers), the soft pretzels didn't taste fresh, and it was odd that the wait staff ordered and ate Giovanni's pizza right on the bar in front of customers. I never like seeing a restaurant staff eat food from another restaurant. Or waitstaff eating in front of customers at all. I like their beer but not a good experience this time.

YD6JE78Pw3_zq1mlQb1P9w.text: It was pretty dead and uneventful for a Friday night. The pretzels were way too salty. I enjoyed the Weizen to wash down all that salt. The beer itself is way better than the atmosphere and experience at the brewpub. There's really no reason to come here. Youre better off going to a bar elsewhere with their beers on tap, or just buying six packs and cases

dG192kJ2lnyGOsIAIsuWzA.text: Does not allow tiny Chihuahua in lap at outdoor tables on quiet afternoon - claiming they are "not allowed" at outdoor tables where there a many many Pittsburgh restaurants that do.  Seriously?  Guess they don't need the business - looked as though they did though.

vx_pN2ClAX1mg_NmLOOjvA.text: Service is friendly but can be hit or miss.  The menu is full of steady and consistent offerings paying homage to the neighborhood's German roots. Penn Brewery is a great place for a stick to your ribs meal in the winter and their Biergarten is wonderful for kicking back with a pint and relaxing with friends in warmer weather. It is waaaay more than just a place to celebrate Oktoberfest (but of course those festivities should not be missed either.)

Rl5LrPmWIiBCzCC49_MA6Q.text: Penn brewery has improved immensely, now that they've abandoned their "German Purity Law" brewing roots.  They are now brewing good, experimental beers as well as their usual house beers. Every month when I've stopped in, they've had something new.   For those of you out of town, Penn is somewhat of a Pittsburgh success story.  They had a rough time a few years back, but the original owner bought back the company and reopened the brew-pub (they were contract brewing for a short while.)  The actual building itself is really cool, and during the summer the outdoor beer garden is open...it sort of feels like you're sitting in an old castle...not too many places where you'd get that feeling in Pittsburgh.    I've eaten here a few times, and while I'm definitely not blown away by the food, it's decent, and it of course goes great with their beer.  They have large portion sizes so don't order too much.  Their hot potato salad, although a little odd, is surprisingly addicting.    Happy hour here is worth mentioning as well . Beers are $3, apps are half price, and on Thursday they do "Beers & Brats" with $5 brats.  I'd go to Penn over Church Sucksworks any day of the week.

ucpO8aI5zvaT8IczlRxYtA.text: Good atmosphere...but the German food was just OK.  Much better German restaurants in Pittsburgh.  Sausage platter was good, pretzels & beer cheese were good, but the Jagerschnitzel was horrible.  The Jagerschnitzel was too thick, heavy breading, way over fried, and very little gravy.  This is a great place for beer and bar food, but go elsewhere for authentic German dishes.

6fsLb-4ukXej157YY4ylhA.text: Great place to go for food and beer. Their beers are hit and miss, but the food is always great. Appetizers, salads, sandwiches, and meals are all awesome. Definitely worth checking out.

IyNf1IXUaGaav5OrIWHifw.text: The place is very nice. Beer and food are very good, actually I liked their food more that Hofbrahaus. They also have live music. The only problem with the place is the location and that's why it's not that crowded on weekends (some people may actually like this). At 10:30 pm there were only 3 tables and a couple of people at the bar.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Penn Weizen

XY870TDtrehrISvvhsxkAg.text: Penn Brewery's Jaeger schnitzel with a side of spaetzle and red cabbage washed down with either a Penn Dark or their delightful Oktoberfest is one of the best dinners ever invented! If there's an Oompah band playing in the background, that just enhances the experience. Their schweinebraten is quite tasty but the Jaeger has my heart. I've ordered that dish in Germany & Austria and Penn's version compares favorably.   Beer and atmosphere here are really fun & cool. Love the outdoor brick courtyard & I especially enjoy when we get seated in the cellar. It's a more intimate space than upstairs which has more of a beer hall atmosphere. I'm not a huge fan of the communal tables on the 1st floor unless you go there with your own big group. Not as much fun with just 2 people.  Penn Brewery is truly a Pittsburgh institution and fortunately when you find one of their beers you like, you can typically find them at a local distributor. We've bought Oktoberfest nearly year round.

ZWLPTOTUnE8rJEirgMOYlQ.text: Great place awesome in summer time with outdoor open. Good food. Great beer. Awesome ocktoberfest!

BBUsHq5qCEGnqvf-gkItMw.text: What's not to like? Local beer ... GREAT local beer.  Good bar food (I did not have an entree ... I gorged myself on appetizers, shame me later). Service was really good ... unusually good. Started at the bar then moved to a table.  I really cannot complain and you know I do LOVE to complain.  If you live in the Burgh and are not a regular here ... I question your taste.

NkqquW5lFWQNAxV2Zv0O-g.text: Do you know what I'm guilty of? It's being out of town and thinking that things are really close and they aren't. At all. I've now made this same mistake in every town and city I've been to and Pittsburgh was no different. We stayed at the William Omni hotel and decided to walk to The Penn Brewery. Google Maps says 1.5 miles so really it didn't seem that bad of a walk -- except there's no real good way to get there. We ended up walking through some park where there was a 5k going on. My husband was smoking and half drunk, while these lovely racers were cheering each other on. Embarrassing or what?  Even despite the really extreme walk in super uncomfortable shoes, I loved Penn Brewery. Maybe I loved it more because I had to walk so far to get there.   Although I like to try new foods, I don't think I've ever had German food, so this was my first dabble in that. I went with the stuffed banana peppers for an entree and the potato pancakes to start. Both were equally delicious and left me wanting to try more of this new culinary treat. However, the stuffed peppers were huge and I really had no room left in my stomach for anything else.  Service was phenomenal until we asked for bus directions. Then no one had any clue and told us to use our phones to get back. Ordinarily that's what we do but both of them happened to be dead. So you know what that means. Another 1.5 mile walk back.   So was it worth the 3 mile walk? Abso-lutely and I'd do it all over again if it meant eating some more of those stuffed peppers.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

CqL6JvkfdiTZhq6K6HfF3w.text: I came here for the Oktoberfest festivities, so I'm not sure if my experience is representative of what can usually be expected at Penn Brewery. Regardless, I had a great time. There was traditional German music, beer (being served in cups and half gallon containers), and food. There was a very wide age range, but everyone was respectful of each other (even with all of the alcohol that was being consumed).   My favorite part of Penn Brewery was the outdoor rooftop patio overlooking the downtown skyline. The ambiance on the reminded me of some of the rooftop bars in New York City.

n7iS50X8vXzSjK2lSti0UQ.text: Good beer. Didn't eat anything but enjoyed our visit. Be warned though, if you order the "full flight" your going to be there a while.

Qx-C2dz84EGmd5Cao4lx0A.text: Oktoberfest 2017 was very disappointing.  I went on 9/16 with my wife and another couple.  We payed $65 each for VIP passes and were very disappointed with the event.  Except for having a VIP line to get drinks and food much quicker, it would have been far cheaper to just pay cash for what was included in our package.  The food was mediocre to say the least: pretzels were cold and the sauerkraut and German potato salad had absolutely zero flavor. It seemed that Penn Brewery was more interested in quantity of patrons rather than the quality of the event. Save your money, there are far better Oktoberfest events to attend.

JrPvHa4oyl8Gqj0r2baIqA.text: In Pitt for the weekend, a buddy recommended I should stop a Penn Brewery. Great, inexpensive beer ~ $3.50 (got the IPA and the Gold). Having never been to Pitt before, the brewery felt like a microcosm of the city; genuine, working class people in a historical, German-rooted neighborhood. Nothing really flashy, just a simple, neat place.

tbfNDp1rCYv0YN1Ys00yIQ.text: We were there today for the 2nd annual King of the Wing Festival.  VIP Tickets cost us $35 each and that gave us 3 hours (2pm-5pm) of unlimited wings from any of 40 or so Pittsburgh area restaurants/bars.  The cheapest tix were $25 and allowed you in from 3-5pm.  The vendors were great!  The options were awesome.  Some of the flavors were not to our liking (maple syrup/real bacon bit wings anyone?), some wings were undercooked (bloody bones inside anyone?).  But some of the vendors hit it out of the park (Big Shot Bobs dry rub is AWESOME!).  We had all kinds of flavors- Jamaican jerk, Cajun, ghost pepper smoked, and tons more.  The reason I'm only giving this 3 stars is because Penn Brewery 'dropped the ball' in several important areas- The outdoor beer stands were cash only.  Who carries cash anymore?  So we headed indoors only to find their ATM machine OUT OF ORDER!  And to get to the ATM you had to leave the parking lot where the event was held and walk completely around to the front of the building to get in.  The gate separating the lot from the restaurant was padlocked!  Why not open it and put a couple I'd checkers on chairs at the gate???  They then put out a single bottled water machine- up on the top lot IN THE SUN!  Then later on they set up a water table in the lower lot (which was shaded) but the water wasn't even iced.  $35 a person and they can't put ice in the water???  There was also a malfunctioning hand wash station- you step on the pedal and the water squirted out all over your feet.  At least there was soap- which I had to rinse off with water from the drinking water table.  I don't know what management was doing but I'm guessing they were oblivious to the issues.  Or maybe they were just too busy counting their money...  Smh...

HG7cyR3OXfOpHDRBV5hdZA.text: The outside looked a bit shady where you had to enter in from some side entrance between the building and the next... The service was amazing - the waiter was fantastic and brought out our food in great fashion.  The food on the other hand was just....okay. It didn't blow me away then again I ordered vegetarian at a German restaurant. Go figure.  The Pierogies weren't anything special - just regular potato.  The pretzels themselves weren't that spectacular either, the thing that made them was the cheese which had a thicker consistency similar to Velveeta... All in all I wouldn't give my left arm to come here again.

3ZqThFdY3szQT-wG5VdMuw.text: Gosh, you must be sick, sick, sick of hearing about this everlasting road trip from Huntington Beach, CA to Philadelphia, PA. Well, if not, thank you for still reading! It took 5 days to get from Surf City to Steel City. We arrived at the Inn at the Mexican War Streets, a gothic mansion purchased in the early 80s by the existing owners for $100k, who, later got it appraised to have $100k worth of blood marble in around the fireplace alone. Nonetheless, it's an incredibly luxurious bed and breakfast for a fantastic price and an opportunity to be part of Pittsburgh's rich history.   The mister and I urban hiked to Penn Brewery, and while I don't have much to say about their beers besides being reminiscent of Budweiser, I do have to say their pretzels were delicious. Chewy and soft inside, the outside provided a pleasantly lye ridden crust. The Original Penn Beer Cheese - basically sharp cheddar blended with cream cheese and Penn pilsner - has become a memorable favorite cheese with the husband. I thought it had a nice bite, but nothing too crazy special. For $4.95 for two large pretzels and a good dose to beer cheese, Penn Brewery gets thumbs up for their knot, not for their beer.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pretzel Throw Down!

EhzoNJRWhoHffaJVjf0_ZA.text: Went there on the night of New Year's Day for dinner. Our server was very nice, but not the greatest, and the food was pretty good but overpriced. I asked for a water with my beer immediately when we got there, I didn't see that water until I had to ask for it again which at that point was when my meal was just about over. Specifically asked for no onions on my burger, which of course came with onions on it. And, when my burger arrived, I waited about 20 minutes before I started eating it because I wanted ketchup, which was not brought out with my meal and our server didn't even make a cameo to check up with us until well after our entrees arrived. I have no inclination to visit Penn Brewery again.

9GsfTnm7qEd3DODUY97i5A.text: I have been coming to the Penn Brewery for most of my life with my Dad and it will always be one of my favorite places to get a bite to eat and now as an adult a fresh pint.  Before you walk in the door you know this is a very unique place in the city. Sitting on Troy Hill this building looks down on historic Deutchetown. The Beer Garden outside is gorgeous cobblestone and a wonderful place to eat in the summer and an even more fun place during Oktoberfest.  The moment the wide wooden doors swing open to reveal the Beer Hall you can't help but admire the beautiful brass brewery equipment peering in through a glass barrier at the charming bar. The long tables call to mind the Prancing Pony and the Green Dragon bringing out my inner nerd.   On my most recent visit I had just finished washing down a delicious soft pretzel with beer cheese and a tall pint of Penn Pilsner when my Cheese steak arrived. I have traveled all over the city looking for the perfect cheesesteak and this is it friends. I have had it more times than I can count and the only plate that can take me away from it is maybe their homemade pierogis.   The prices are extremely reasonable for what you get and the experience is unlike any other this side of the Atlantic. I've never had their mixed drinks but only come here of you like beer.

Jz4_SeqY890gv1Z1A3jupg.text: This is one of the spots I feel lucky we have in the Burgh! I mean, really lucky considering it shuttered its doors for a number of years and reopened semi-recently.   You can't beat this fun of an environment. Toss away the generic Hofbrauhaus get to a Pittsburgh legacy! I love the fun German beer hall feel with the large picnic size tables that just beckon you to sit down with an even larger brew!  I love German food, but there's a really good opportunity to screw it up. Have you ever noticed a lot of the colors of German food blend together? Sauerkraut, perogies, mashed taters (is that German? Whatever!), they all look the same! So making them taste good is a must! I'm a big fan of the perogies - a buttery delicious mixture in a lovely little dumpling. While I'm not really a fan of their sauerkraut, it's too sweet for me, I know some people like it that way (I like mine a little on the sour side). Throw in a pretzel with their beer cheese and some grilled kielbasa and I'm one happy German camper!  I'm a fan of their Penn Pilsner and a big big big fan of their special Chocolate Meltdown, which they debuted last Valentines Day. Now I'm telling you right now, you get yourself to Penn Brewery AS SOON as that comes out this year!  The other thing that's awesome about this place is that they throw a ton of events. Nevermind their month long Oktoberfest, they host bands every couple weeks that jam out inside and out. Speaking of which, they have a great outdoor courtyard for sitting with your fave brew!   And to that I say, oh! oh! oh!

uh8eb0hWBEqrsT6UH7mRlg.text: If you want a good German meal- seek no more. This is it.   Absolutely superb.    The spaetzle is the best I've ever had. I've been to other German restaurants in the burgh and this puts them to shame!!!

xpEeSyuUX7knrqtiRrUxzQ.text: Service was terrible.  Waitress barely came to our table and was not very friendly. I got bier cheese macaroni and it tasted like nothing but yeast. My boyfriend got a chicken sandwich and the chicken wasn't even seasoned. Got an Oktoberfest beer that tasted very cheap and had no flavor.

z76TYU2sO8y6jtEhoqepwA.text: Very nice venue, partook in the outside seating...it was wonderful, food was great, as was the beer and service... had a unique Reuben, composed of thin sliced Kielbasa, excellent!...only negative, which was huge, was that they allowed smoking in the center of the courtyard...unfortunately we sat where a chain smoker was seated at the bar...spoke to a manager, but he was not sure of policy...did speak to the smoking gentleman, who left, but was immediately replaced by another...the solution is to move the smoking area out to one of the courtyard perimeter locations!... once that is accomplished, I would rate this as one of the best brewery restaurants in the city!

8MiBpxFjxJLmK2X5E8yJAQ.text: I've been wanting to try Penn Brewery since I moved to Pittsburgh.  I've heard good things about both the food and the service.  I finally made it there last weekend and was pleased with my visit.  I initially tried to visit last weekend, but it was so packed there was over an hour wait for a table, so we decided to return in the future but with reservations.  I was glad I had made them because even fairly early they were crowded.    They have happy hour specials from 5-7 which include half price appetizers and beer and drink specials.  Because of the specials, we tried the Buffalo chicken pierogies, potato pancakes and the beer cheese.  All were fantastic!  Being from Buffalo, I was especially excited to try the Buffalo Chicken pierogies since I've never had anything like them before.  My only complaint is that they were slightly dry, but the flavor was fantastic.  Entrees were the weinerschnitzel and sausage platter.  Both were very tasty, however my schnitzel was a bit dry (remedied by eating it with bites of the cabbage).  I was going to order it with the sauce, but the server advised it is bitter and almost no one likes it.  I'm glad he gave me the tip, but if no one likes it, you would think they would change the recipe to improve that aspect.  Oh well.  Service was good.  Almost too good in that all of our food came out very quickly.  We had other places to be that evening, so in the scheme of things, it wasn't a bad thing, but to some degree, we almost felt rushed.  Beer was amazing.  Had the nut roll ale and the Christmas blend.  I wish I would have bought some to take home with me.  There will be a return visit.

G4C6io2kO4JwIijK0D7gVw.text: Really great atmosphere! Good quality German food and beer. They had a ginger beer that was tasty. Schnitzel was good. Our waiter was nice and was quick to joke with us when we said silly things. If you want German food, skip Hofbrau and come here!

2tQZVbM10Cx8OXw06OuQQg.text: Went here on my last trip to Pittsburgh. I've been here several times years ago. I had the jaegerschnitzel with sauerkraut instead of potato's. The food was excellent breaded very lightly and not tough. It had a nice mushroom sauce on top of the schnitzel. The vegetable was broccoli I think which excellent. Then there was the beer. They brew their own here so I tried an IPA. Very tasty. I sat at the bar and the dining was very casual.

JJSnq_D7U6pXgZ3RCW6vNA.text: This is one of the best breweries we have been at.  The beers were great tasting, and the food was spectacular!!!!  Couldn't beat the location.  Service was terrific!!!!

98XO8rYV_fvAfLdSUdoA6Q.text: YUM! I've been to Penn Brewery a couple times and have to say, I really, really enjoy eating at this place and I am so glad it's part of Pittsburgh! Well done German food + authentic German beers: what's not to like?  The first time I stopped in was for lunch and I fell in love immediately. The place wasn't hopping but that was fine by me - my dining companion and I had plenty of room to stretch out in their tavern/hall-like dining area as we peered into the brewery and tried remembering which flags on the walls and in the rafters represented which countries. For our meal, we ordered their ginger beer - an excellent brew! - and a specialty veal sandwich (which I wish they'd add to the menu full-time!), amazing pierogies and an absolutely delicious green salad. Seriously, you know you're doing something right when I get super happy about a salad - what's not to like about being able to eat well without giving up taste? This one had smoked pork belly, dried cranberries, mozzarella, and almonds dressed with garlic oil vinegar. Talk about yummy!  My second visit was during dinner hours with a group of friends, and I honestly think I'll be sticking to lunch only visits. The place was much more packed in the evening and once you added in loud music, it was impossible to talk to anyone at my table aside from the person right next to me. Not cool - if I'm out with friends, I want to be able to talk to them. Still, the food was as awesome as ever - we split the fried pickles (quite unusual in this city, I think, but not bad) and I continued my streak of ordering "healthier" options here by getting the portobello stack. Given it's price I wouldn't have minded a bit more food on my plate - but it was still VERY good. Well cooked (but not overdone) mushrooms plus tomatoes plus creamy goat cheese and dressing - what a simple but delectable combination. Seeing as I'd eaten beer and pizza at work that day, a dinner of just vegetables sounded perfect, and it's good to know that Penn Brewery's menu isn't entirely comprised of heavy German food, a common sin of restaurants that offer it.  I definitely plan on stopping in to sample more of their sandwiches, appetizers and burgers the next time I want to go out for lunch - just thinking about trying their Deutschtaun Burger and their flatbreads makes my mouth water!

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. A perfect meal - beer, spinach salad and one of their amazing sandwiches.
Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Delicious ginger beer!
Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

CxgiRVB-6Dod2rWeLbV9iw.text: I haven't been to Penn Brewery in so long. But I like that I can get the beer just about anywhere. The brewery itself is laid out and decorated with flair and I especially like the outside patio seating within an urban setting. Food on the menu is good as well. I know you're on the edge of your seats wondering what my favorite pour is and I'll tell ya: Chocolate Meltdown!!

gkckHgfmPr4iK_pE2FSkaw.text: I came here for the deustchtown music fest, and was immediately overwhelmed. It was naturally busy, but there were so many different levels and spaces to access with little direction. The menu was disappointing for a vegetarian so I ended up not eating. The staff inside didn't know where to direct us or just didn't care. I get it, they were busy, but their job is to help us enjoy the space.  Negatives aside, the space itself is great. There are tons of areas to explore and relax with good beer. The sound was also well done, and that impressed me.   I'm not sure I'll be back anytime soon. It's just not my vibe, and it's pretty far out of the way for drinking and chilling. I strongly recommend supporting them by buying their local beer though, because that's the cool thing to do.

UY9RyYd67X6xYlW3Kl-3cQ.text: Let me start off by saying the beer here is amazing. I frequently come to the Penn Brewery to grab one of their IPA or Ginger beers to enjoy in the outdoor area. Never disappointed. Do note it's not self seating and it's very easy to walk into the biergarten from the street and not be waited on. The food on the other hand, I find lacking. I ordered beer cheese and macaroni "I'm a huge fan of bier cheese and pretzels" but when my dish arrived, the cheese was watered down and seriously lacking in taste. For the price and what I knew from the quality of the beer, I was surprised and disappointed in the food. It's also quite loud inside on the weekends.

p8PoGWooajQql1J7Je2PLw.text: Just stopped in for a light lunch after going to the Warhol. Unfortunately the wait staff wasn't too interested in serving us? When they finally arrived they said they were busy but there were a lot of empty tables! Not sure how they would handle a real rush? Had heard goods reviews but will not be returning next time I visit Pittsburgh. We went to Fatheads instead and the food, beer and service were great!

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

k1EhdkY4jxMRQOjVeYCs_g.text: After many visits to Penn Brewery, I have to say I'm usually more a fan of their food than their beer.  Their seasonals are often my favorites, like the Oktoberfest.  I've also recently discovered their Summer Berry Weiss and enjoyed it so much that I finally purchased a Penn Brewery growler.  They make some pretty tasty German fare here that never disappoints.  My go-to has often been the amazing sausage platter.  On my most recent trip I did a 180 and went for the Beer Garden Burger and could not have been happier with the selection.  I'm far from being a vegetarian, but this burger was something I would definitely eat again.    They also host some awesome events such as their own Oktoberfest, a Brewfest featuring other local/regional offerings and most recently the Northside Sandwich Sampler.  Thursdays during the summer they have the Beer Garden open for cheap drinks and food.    I've been here when it's jam-packed busy and I've been here when I thought they were closed because there were only two other patrons.  Not much of a bar area, but tables both upstairs and down.  Regardless of the time of day or number of other customers, the service, food and beer have always been good.  Drink local.

XxEvrC5SzCuJcnma37my0w.text: We LOVE this place! Beer in authentic German style, the pub food follows suit. All food offerings tasty and exhibit deeply savory developed flavors that shine! The staff is attentive and customer friendly. Most especially Chad the bartender! He is funny, friendly and so kind. The Penn beer samplers are the wtg for first timers. We love the seasonal offerings as well! A must are the pretzels & beer cheese.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

wdSZsSRVI9IFW2hY26KwEA.text: A visit to Penn Brewery is a must if you are a beer lover like me.  A choice of 5 or 10 beer flights! I was tempted to try them all out but unfortunately my travel mates are not beer drinkers... (pop/water drinkers).   My beer flight ($10) even includes their Okotober Bier... which is one of my fave out of all!  Sausage Platter ($7.95) with hot German potato salad on the side. The sourness of the salad does need to get use to but it is great to balance the meatiness of the sausages.  My next trip for sure will include a Happy Hour stop here at Penn Brewery! $3 for a Pint and 1/2 off appetizer... that's would be such a sweet deal.

U0Np2oVC8iKrEFxD_B5Q5A.text: the atmosphere is shared picnic tables, some high tops,  funky lighting, views into the brewery.  I had the best ginger beer here i had in a month long cross country trip across the USA. DH and I shared an unusual  mushroom spaetzle which was rich, tasty and memorable.... we also had cheeses/ crackers for an appetizer.... Just awesome.. will make a stop back as there were several places in Pittsbugh we ran out of time to visit...

q8Oi8DUUeAJnj2NoIC7Yaw.text: I used to LOVE the Penn Brewery.  My dad had his 50th birthday there, i had my 30th birthday there, the food was great, the music was great, and dont even get me started  about the time i accidentally drank an entire gallon of beer at Oktoberfest bc they were serving the beer in half gallon jugs and after you drink half a gallon of beer, it seems like a good idea to have another!  (I had a DD).  Its under new management and only the location is still the same.  And the beer.  So I might be back for Oktober fest only, this time sticking to half a half a gallon.    How changed is my beloved German restaurant?  Four words.  Dave Matthews Cover Band.  WTF.    If I ever come back for food, it wont be on a Saturday night.  Because of nostalgia I've tried this place three times, but due to my schedule its unfortunately been on a Saturday night which is apparently "Bands that sound like your sitting in a dorm room listening to your crush play guitar and sing but he cant sing and hes just learning guitar but you prentend to like it anyway" night.  Who the hell is their booker?  Why is it SO DAMN LOUD in the bar I couldn't talk to my friend, instead we kind of sat there and watched the beer ripple in our glasses.  The accoustics are equally bad upstairs and downstairs.  Its terrible.  If you must keep the same music booker, can you PLEASE have your bands turn the volume down, just a little.  And for the record, I love music.  But it's quieter at Stage AE.  its just assinine.    Since youre not going to be able to HEAR or TALK to your dining companions, you can look forward to the food which is just slightly better than ok.  The schnitzel is pretty good, but I dont know why this restaurant even tries to maintain that they are a german restaurant.  Why not just become a brew pub, and have a menu with really good bar food?  This place is a disappointment.  But theres really good beer here, and that makes it worth it to check it out one lsat time before realizing its just never going to be the same restaurant it once was.

n-rhnCZ-8J9zggYViFGxYA.text: Initial impression is not good....wanted to sit at the bar....only a few open seats behind the overly large taps that obstruct the view of the beer selection board and the tv.....the manager firmly planted himself and his laptop at the end of the bar taking an available seat away from us.  He sat there the whole time....he should have gone someplace else to do his work.  This all happened before we had one beer...on a good note the beer was good....the initial impression left a bad taste in our mouth.

-EqZ_Q_zctEBZ2KCKC5rKg.text: Penn Brewery had been on my list of places to try for quite some time (plus I had a groupon to use!). I'm kind of sad that we waited this long to finally eat there. Our food was delicious and the dinner portions were very filling.  The atmosphere and building itself are pretty neat, as well as the outdoor Biergarten area.  Only complaint of the evening was our so-so waitress, very nice, but very scarce and not assertive at all when I had some questions about the menu, and how to properly pronounce Jaegerschnitzel.

photos.caption: Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Sausage plate and jaegerschnitzel

ZU0Rti3Dy-y_23YMFc-RXw.text: Penn Brewery HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!  Authentic German Bier + GREAT food, especially during October Fest!   Their Sour Weis beer is awesome as are their Pretzel app!

Photo of Penn Brewery - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Jäger schnitzel was OUTSTANDING!

G1b7qMVR6Jd-4e5FKOsJVA.text: I've been to this restaurant twice. The first time was good enough to warrant a second trip, but it's unlikely I'll make a third. Most recently I went on a Saturday night. The server informed us that only two beers were available on tap and the others were bottled, which considering the restaurant is at the brewery reflects poorly on the way the place is managed.  Incredibly loud music that sounded like top 40 country radio played over the speakers, which isn't the sort of atmosphere I want if I'm going to a German style brew pub. My saurbraten was very tough. The pretzel appetizers were OK but were typical chain style food and overpriced for the quality. The server didn't inquire how anything was and generally seemed annoyed to be there. The beer is available elsewhere and the service, atmosphere, and food were mediocre at best. I see no reason to go back.

Ci8X7_2Rb7KlQAuo5_sQ4Q.text: I go to their Oktoberfest every year, I would not miss it.  I love the live music, the great food, dancing, and of course the fabulous beer.  But it's nice to go back occasionally when things are less hectic and crowded, and what I get is really good German food and some of the best beers made in Pittsburgh.  There's an Old World taste to the beer made here and it's authentic and satisfying.  The Penn Brewery is a real gem!

hD77ya--yQ8kqBbKHZ1v3Q.text: Love it once again! Hadn't been to the place in about a year since I was trying some new places. It must have gone through some big changes .The beer is exceptional as always but the food has gotten 100x better homestly. Mac and cheese was excellent, burger was excellent, schnitzel sandwich was really good. Once again I'll definitely be back soon to enjoy more of the food and beers! Good job guys. Welcome back .

ucCAWyrVMzbgFJyrGEPuCw.text: I was surprised at how much I liked this place. Really great beer! I was so surprised at how great the spicy ginger beer was! And the flatbread and sausages we ordered were out of this world! Will definitely frequent again!

qi50syuqjlVlTiMJXei3Rg.text: Service was poor and very slow.  Not sure if our server had too many tables at once or what the problem was.  She was nice, just did not have things timed out right at all.  We waited 20 minutes for our check then another 10 to get it back.  I hope this improves future service.
